description.hltext_display: Make the most of your Christmas meal
description.author: RITA DEMONTIS
description.content:
If anyone knows about planning for a party, it's Cara Epp, a well-respected Canadian food and beverage marketing specialist who knows her way around the supermarket.
Over the years she has hosted (and survived!) countless holiday dinner parties for her large extended family and friends.
Here, Cara offers good food for thought when planning the Big Event - Christmas dinner. In the meantime, heed these sage words of advice:
TEN TOP TIPS FOR A SUCCESSFUL CHRISTMAS DINNER: 1. Follow Santa?s lead ? planning is key for a successful Christmas dinner. Write down everything you need ? from table decor and entertainment to appetizers and the main course. Make a list and check it twice.
2. Many people have special recipes that they only serve at holiday time. Invite your guests to bring a dish that says ?Christmas? to them. It will lighten your load, instantly make your guests feel at home, and will be a great conversation starter.
3. Purchase all the non-perishable items in advance. Christmas crackers, table décor, soft drinks and alcohol ? stock up and store it.
4. From tables and chairs to tableware - whatever you can?t beg, borrow or steal, consider renting from a party rental store at a fraction of the cost of purchasing.
5. Preparing dishes ahead of time = less mess and less stress. Many side dishes, soups and desserts can be prepared in advance and either frozen or stored in the fridge for a day or two. Search online for make-ahead recipes ? for example, Turkeyrecipes.ca has delicious stuffing recipes that can be made and frozen up to four weeks in advance.
6. Create a drink station and allow guests to serve themselves. Assign a member of the family to replenish supplies as needed.
7. Serve appetizers that can be set out before guests arrive. The Ultimate Appetizer collection found in the recipe section at Ontariomeatproducts.ca has many simple but elegant ideas for appetizers and hors d?oeuvres that can be served hot or cold.
8. Set your table in advance. If you can keep kids and pets away, do it a day or two ahead. If not, at least aim to get it done early on in the day.
9. Put an iPod-savvy teen in charge of preparing a suitable playlist. When your guests RSVP, ask them for their favourite holiday song selections. Go online to purchase songs that you may not have in your personal collection.
10. Have games, activities and kid appropriate-snacks prepared to keep your younger guests occupied ? preferably in an area that you don?t mind a mess. If you have a tween or two who will be in attendance, offer them a modest sum to help entertain the little ones.
- Check out Caraepp.ca for more ideas!
ROASTED VEGETABLE MEDLEY
Seasonal vegetables are so tasty when their sweetness and texture is showcased. A mixture of vegetables will give you slightly different textures and most certainly delicious flavour. A drizzle of maple syrup really finishes off these roasted beauties. Recipe courtesy of Longo's (longos.com).
2 small red onions
4 parsnips, peeled and cut into 1-inch (2.5cm) cubes
1/2 rutabaga, peeled and cut into 1-inch (2.5cm) cubes
1 sweet potato, peeled and cut into 1-inch (2.5cm) cubes
3 Tbsp. (45ml) extra-virgin olive oil
2 cloves garlic, minced
2 Tbsp. (30ml) each chopped fresh oregano and thyme
1/2 tsp. (2.5ml) each salt and pepper
2 Tbsp. (30ml) maple syrup
1 Tbsp. (15ml) chopped fresh Italian parsley
Cut each onion into 8 wedges and place in large bowl. Add parsnips, rutabaga and sweet potato. Drizzle with oil and add garlic, oregano, thyme, salt and pepper and toss to combine. Scrape vegetables onto a parchment paper-lined baking sheet and roast in 425F (220C) oven for about 45 minutes, stirring twice or until golden brown and tender. Remove to large bowl and drizzle with maple syrup and sprinkle with parsley before serving.
Serves 8.
RICE-STUFFED CROWN OF LAMB
Looking for something a little different this Christmas? Start by giving the turkey a rest! Create a royal feast for your family this holiday with a crown roast of lamb. Stuffed with an asparagus and shiitake mushroom rice pilaf and topped with an easy-to-make beurre blanc sauce, this roast contains two dishes in one. Recipe courtesy of USA Rice (Riceinfo.com). Lamb:
1 Tbsp. (15 ml) EACH, butter, softened, grainy Dijon mustard and chopped fresh rosemary
1/2 tsp (2 ml) EACH coarse salt and freshly cracked black pepper
1 crown of lamb, made from two 8-rib racks (approx. 4 lbs/2 kg)
Rice:
1 Tbsp. (15 ml) butter
1/2 cup (125 ml) minced shallots
1 cup (250 ml) sliced shiitake mushrooms
1/2 tsp. (2 ml) EACH coarse salt and freshly cracked black pepper
1- 1/2 cups (375 ml) long grain white rice
1 cup (250 ml) white wine
2 cups (500 ml) chicken broth
3 cups (750 ml) chopped asparagus
1 Tbsp. (15 ml) lemon zest
1 Tbsp. (15 mL) chopped fresh mint
Sauce:
1 Tbsp. (15 ml) butter
2 large shallots, minced
1 cup (250 ml) EACH dry white wine and chicken broth
¼ cup (50 ml) chopped fresh chives
In a small bowl, stir together butter, mustard, rosemary, salt and pepper to make a paste.
Arrange roast in centre of a roasting pan. Rub paste all over roast. Refrigerate for at least one hour and up to one day.
Meanwhile, in a large deep skillet, heat butter over medium-high heat. Add shallots, stirring often, until tender, but not browned, about 5 minutes. Add mushrooms, salt and pepper and cook stirring often, until golden, about 7 minutes.
Stir in rice until well-coated with butter and starting to make a popping sound, about one minute.
Pour in white wine and let it reduce until almost all absorbed, stirring occasionally, about 5 minutes.
Stir in chicken broth, cover and reduce heat to maintain a gentle simmer; cook until almost all liquid has been absorbed and rice is al dente, about 15 minutes.
In a small pot of boiling salted water, cook asparagus for 30 seconds. Rinse quickly under cold water until completely cooled. Gently stir asparagus, lemon zest and mint into the rice mixture. Set aside.
Roast lamb in a 350F (180C) oven for 20 minutes. Spoon rice mixture into centre, and return to oven until lamb reaches desired doneness, about 15 minutes for medium rare 160F (70C) (time will vary significantly, depending on the size of the lamb). Let rest 10 minutes before serving.
While lamb is resting, in medium saucepan, melt butter over medium-high heat. Cook shallots, until tender, about 5 minutes. Stir in wine and cook until reduced by half, about 3 minutes. Add broth and chives and cook down until slightly thickened, about 2 minutes. Spoon sauce over servings of lamb alongside rice.
Makes 8 servings.
CHOCOLATE SHORTBREAD AND EGGNOG TRIFLE
This show-stopping holiday dessert features real cream and is guaranteed to become a family-favourite treat. Recipe courtesy of Dairy Farmers of Canada.
8 oz (250 g) white chocolate, chopped 1/3 cup (75 ml) water 1/4 cup (50 ml) rum 1 1/2 cups (375 ml) Canadian Mascarpone Cheese (35% M.F.) 1 tsp (5 ml) ground nutmeg 1 1/2 cups (375 ml) semi-sweet chocolate chips 4 cups (1 L) broken shortbread cookies (including any crumbs) 2 cups (500 ml) 35% whipping cream 3 cups (750 ml) raspberries, divided
In large microwave-safe bowl, combine white chocolate, water and rum; heat on High (100%) power for 1-1/2 min, or until chocolate melts; whisk until smooth. Add Canadian Mascarpone cheese and nutmeg, whisk until mixture is smooth; refrigerate until mixture is barely lukewarm, about 45 minutes. Meanwhile, line a baking sheet with parchment paper. In large microwave-safe bowl, on Medium (50%) power, microwave chocolate chips for about 2 minutes, stirring twice, until chips are melted. Add broken cookies and crumbs and toss until coated in chocolate.
Place on baking sheet; chill for about 10 min or until chocolate is hardened. Break chunks into smaller pieces using parchment to contain all the bits; reserve 2 tbsp (30 mL) to garnish. In a chilled, straight-sided bowl, whip cream just until soft peaks form; fold into Mascarpone mixture. Cover and chill this eggnog mousse filling until set, about 2 hours. Arrange one-third of the chocolate cookie pieces to line a 12-cup (3 L) trifle or glass bowl. Layer one-third of eggnog mousse filling; top with 1-1/2 cups (375 mL) raspberries, then sprinkle with one-third of the chocolate cookie pieces. Spread one-third of the eggnog mousse, top with 1-1/4 cup (300 mL) raspberries and sprinkle remaining one-third of the chocolate cookie pieces. Spread remaining mousse. Cover and refrigerate for up to 8 hours. Garnish with remaining raspberries and reserved cookie pieces.
Serves 12.

description.hltext_display: Australia in 2010
description.content: The kingmakers - Windsor, Oakeshott and Katter held the nation's fate in their hands for more than two weeks. (AAP) Australia began the year with a man named Kevin Rudd serving as Prime Minister, and ended it with his former deputy filling the role.From the hung parliament to debates over mining, broadband and water, politics dominated the National news agenda in 2010. 25th February The international row over the suspected hit on a senior Hamas figure in a Dubai hotel room keeps growing. In late February, it becomes apparent that . In May, Australia expels an Israeli diplomat in retaliation. 29th March In March, after a closely followed trial, a Chinese court convicts four employees of mining giant Rio Tinto, , to jail on charges of bribery and trade secrets. Later in the year, the role of mining in Australias future prosperity would increasingly take centre stage following the Henry Tax Review. April 19th Notorious Melbourne gangland figure following an attack in his jail cell. Public interest is high due to Williams celebrity-like status and the popularity of the Underbelly TV series. Charges are laid later in the year. April 22nd The Melbourne Storm are dealt the heavy blow of losing a host of titles after the NRL team in order hide salary cap breaches. The issue moves beyond sport, bringing in to question News Ltd and the management of the game as a whole. April 27th An agreement on an Emissions Trading Scheme had already cost Liberal Leader Malcolm Turnbull his job, but now, the issue that Prime Minister Rudd had publicly pushed so hard far is . Rudd blames the Opposition, but commentators later queue up to single out this delay as one of the defining moments in the downfall of Rudd. 2nd May Labor announces what will become a key election issue, the proposal to dramatically increase the rate at which big mining companies are taxed, branding it the Come poll time, the ALP will have a fight on its hands to defend the policy it says is in the interest of fair returns for everyday Australians. 22nd June Although Australias involvement in Afghanistan is fading from the public mind, the issue soon hits home again with the naming of in a helicopter crash. If only briefly, the debate about Australian involvement is reignited. 23rd June It all happened so quickly. One minute he was Prime Minster, the next minute Kevin Rudd was . The issue which would lead to a knife-edge election led to much soul-searching about the direction of the ALP and the issue of opinion-polling in Australian politics. 24th June In her first speech as Prime Minister, Julia Gillard announces that Internet message boards, TV and radio airwaves are filled with voices from the left and right expressing their shock. The new PM will soon call a federal election. 30th July Labor releases a series of maps showing . Come the haggling over the federal election results, the NBN, and the Coaltions opposition to it, is cited as a key reason for three of the four independents siding with Labor. 2nd August News that former David Jones publicist Kristy Anne Fraser-Kirk is and the chain for over $37m grabs the attention of the country. The boss of the store with the household name had already resigned in June after he admitted to behaving "in a manner unbecoming of a chief executive to a female staff member" at two recent company functions. 21st/22nd August No amount of superlatives could do the election justice. After one of the tightest Canberra races in history, , and weeks of haggling over just who would get to form government. The insatiable media spotlight soon turns to the independents and first ever Greens MP, Adam Bandt. The election also produces the first ever indigenous MP, Ken Wyatt, the youngest ever, Wyatt Roy and, the first Muslim-born MP, Ed Husic. 7th September After a nailbiting two weeks, the kingmaking duo (or in this case, queenmaking) of Rob Oakeshott and Tony Windsor finally after Bob Katter chose not to. The decision, coupled with that of independent Andrew Wilkie and Greens MP Adam Bandt, means Labor narrowly clings to power. 27th September News that three Australian soldiers charged over the deaths of five children in Afghanistan have been charged, leads to heated debate. amid claims that the government should take the unprecedented step of intervening in the decision of the Director of Military Prosecutions to charge the men. 28th September Next Top Model host Sarah Murdoch is left truly embarrassed after she , on September 28. Murdoch was reportedly fed the wrong information through her ear-piece. In a swift PR manoeuvre, runner-up Kelsey Martinovich was given a trip to New York and awarded $25,000 as a prize. 8th October Exporters fret and online shoppers react with glee to news that the . The dollar goes on to hover around the parity mark, with a surge in Australian tourists heading to the US predicted. 17th October Australian Catholics celebrate the canonization of Australias first Catholic saint, Mary MacKillop, who is 18th October Anger grows amongst rural communities affected by cuts to their water use proposed by the Murray Darling Basin Authority. The government says in order to save the Basin from environmental disaster. 3rd November The issue of banking reform keeps growing following the big banks decisions to raise interest rates - blaming the RBA. Joe Hockey has been pushing the issue for the Coalition, but following derision from Labor benches, the government sees the writing on the wall 14th December Did someone say Oprah? To the delight of Oprah fans and tourism officials, and the disdain of many others, . Sydneys CBD is shut down, and fans and stars descend on the Opera House. 15th December The human face of boat people becomes apparent across the media spectrum when shocking images of a at Christmas Island emerge. Over the following days, the Prime Minister announces the possible death toll from the tragedy could rise as high as 48.

description.hltext_display: Sốt xuất huyết: Vì sao khỏe rồi tử vong?
description.content:
Điều trị bệnh nhân sốt xuất huyết tại bệnh viện - Ảnh: THANH ĐẠM
Ngày 6-12, bé T.K.M.K. (6 tuổi, ngụ Q.1, TP.HCM) đã tử vong tại Bệnh viện (BV) Bệnh nhiệt đới TP.HCM sau hơn ba tuần điều trị tại bệnh viện này.
Anh T.V.D., cha của bé M.K., cho biết ngày 11-11 bé M.K. được gia đình đưa đến BV Bệnh nhiệt đới TP khám vì sốt cao. Bác sĩ khám, cho xét nghiệm máu và chẩn đoán bé bị sốt phát ban, cho toa thuốc.
Hai ngày sau bé K. vẫn sốt, gia đình lại đưa bé đến BV Bệnh nhiệt đới thì bác sĩ chẩn đoán bị sốt xuất huyết độ 4. Bé nằm viện hơn 20 ngày. Bác sĩ thông báo với gia đình bé đã qua cơn nguy kịch. Thế nhưng, bé đột nhiên bị trào máu miệng và tử vong. Theo anh T.V.D., bác sĩ đã tắc trách trong chẩn đoán ban đầu. Đến nay gia đình không biết vì sao bé K. đã khỏe rồi lại đột ngột tử vong.
TS.BS Nguyễn Văn Vĩnh Châu - phó giám đốc BV Bệnh nhiệt đới TP - trả lời 14g ngày 11-11, bé đến khám tại phòng khám BV, bé có những nốt đỏ lớn ở da, được chẩn đoán là sốt phát ban vào ngày thứ ba của bệnh tại thời điểm này là phù hợp với biểu hiện lâm sàng của sốt phát ban do siêu vi. Ngày 12 và 13-11
(ngày thứ 4 và 5 của sốt), bé ở nhà uống thuốc theo toa, hết sốt. Đến chiều 13-11 bé có biểu hiện bỏ ăn, mệt và nhập viện BV Bệnh nhiệt đới lúc 18g25 ngày 13-11. Khi nhập khoa hồi sức bé đã ở tình trạng đừ, mạch, huyết áp không đo được.
Các xét nghiệm ngay khi bắt đầu điều trị đã thấy có tổn thương nhiều cơ quan gồm gan, thận, rối loạn đông máu. Diễn tiến lâm sàng và xét nghiệm cho thấy bé bị sốt xuất huyết độ 4, sốc kéo dài, suy đa phủ tạng (suy tuần hoàn, suy gan, suy thận, rối loạn đông máu, xuất huyết tiêu hóa nặng), tiên lượng rất nặng có nguy cơ tử vong cao ngay tại thời điểm đó.
Bác sĩ điều trị đã thông báo và tư vấn cho thân nhân đầy đủ.
Bé được điều trị theo đúng phác đồ dành cho những trường hợp sốt xuất huyết nặng và theo dõi chặt chẽ. Qua 23 ngày điều trị, những vấn đề nguy hiểm có thể đe dọa tử vong do sốt xuất huyết nặng của bé đã được giải quyết.
Các ca trực đêm 5-12 cũng như thăm khám của bác sĩ tại khoa trong buổi sáng cho đến 8g ngày 6-12 đều nhận thấy tình trạng sức khỏe của bé ổn định, bé được chuyển sang thở oxy mũi. Bé hoàn toàn tỉnh táo, đòi ăn uống, nói chuyện với người nhà; không có dấu hiệu báo trước diễn tiến nặng trở lại như suy hô hấp, suy tim...
Tuy nhiên, khoảng 8g30 ngày 6-12, bé đột ngột ho ọc ra máu đỏ tươi lẫn bọt và trụy mạch do bị xuất huyết ồ ạt từ phổi. Diễn tiến trở nặng của bé xảy ra đột ngột, trong thời gian rất ngắn. Do đó nguyên nhân dẫn tới tử vong có thể do xuất huyết phổi cấp tính vì vỡ mạch máu làm ngập phổi dẫn tới suy hô hấp và tử vong.
Đây là tình trạng bệnh lý rất nặng, có thể do biến chứng của thở máy dài ngày gây sang chấn niêm mạc đường hô hấp gây xuất huyết ồ ạt, rất ít cơ may điều trị khỏi. Theo y văn, những trường hợp này khá hiếm gặp.
Bệnh có thể trở nặng nhanh chóng
TS.BS Nguyễn Văn Vĩnh Châu cho biết:
- Bệnh sốt xuất huyết có diễn tiến đa dạng và phức tạp. Khởi đầu của bệnh thường có triệu chứng sốt cao liên tục, uống thuốc hạ sốt không bớt, do đó trong giai đoạn đầu bệnh nhân thường được chẩn đoán là sốt siêu vi.
Ngoài ra, bệnh còn có các triệu chứng có thể gặp trong nhiều bệnh lý nhiễm siêu vi khác như: đau họng, ho, họng đỏ (tương tự viêm họng), nhức mỏi và đau cơ (tương tự bệnh cúm), nổi những nốt đỏ trên da không phải do xuất huyết trong 2-3 ngày đầu (tương tự biểu hiện trong bệnh sốt phát ban do siêu vi khác như sốt phát ban do rubella, sởi...).
Ở giai đoạn đầu, việc chẩn đoán phân biệt giữa sốt xuất huyết với các bệnh nhiễm siêu vi có sốt khác là rất khó
* Triệu chứng báo hiệu sốt xuất huyết ra sao?
- Khi một bệnh nhân sống trong vùng có dịch sốt xuất huyết đang xảy ra, có sốt cao liên tục thì cần đặc biệt theo dõi những dấu hiệu cảnh báo của bệnh vào những ngày 4,5,6 tính từ khi bị sốt, để nhanh chóng đưa tới cơ sở y tế ngay lập tức.
Các dấu hiệu cảnh báo là: đau bụng và căng tức, ói liên tục, chảy máu niêm mạc, li bì, bứt rứt, vùng gan to, đau. Với những trường hợp nghi ngờ sốt xuất huyết mà không có dấu hiệu cảnh báo có thể theo dõi điều trị tại nhà.
Cần lưu ý, bệnh sốt xuất huyết dù được chẩn đoán chính xác ngay từ ngày đầu tiên của sốt thì đến nay y học vẫn chưa có biện pháp điều trị đặc hiệu để ngăn ngừa bệnh trở nặng (vào khoảng ngày thứ 4-6 của bệnh) và bệnh cũng có thể trở nặng rất nhanh chóng, từ độ 1 chuyển ngay sang độ 3 hoặc độ 4.
* Điều trị sốt xuất huyết thế nào, thưa bác sĩ?
- Việc điều trị bệnh sốt xuất huyết-D cho đến nay chỉ là giải quyết triệu chứng, chưa có thuốc đặc trị diệt virus cũng như thuốc ngăn chặn quá trình thoát mạch huyết tương (gây sốc sốt xuất huyết) hoặc quá trình xuất huyết.
Cụ thể, bệnh nhân sốt thì dùng thuốc hạ sốt và uống nhiều nước; khi bệnh trở nặng, vào sốc thì dùng dịch truyền tĩnh mạch để bồi hoàn thể tích dịch tuần hoàn; khi chảy máu nhiều thì truyền máu...

description.hltext_display: Gerald Thomas Buxton
description.content:
He was born on Aug. 11, 1913, in Vernon County to Otis and Bina (Getter) Buxton. Gerald was an active member of the Viroqua Church of Christ. He was united in marriage to Alma Hanson on Oct. 27, 1936. They farmed for many years on Pleasant Ridge. He was on the Pleasant Ridge School Board for 12 years. He retired from farming and moved to Viroqua in 1975.
Alma passed away on Jan. 28, 1976. Gerald remarried Irene Olson in March of 1977. Irene passed away Dec. 13, 2004.
Gerald enjoyed gardening, fishing, his beautiful Christmas cactus and playing 500 Rummy with his girls. Gerald loved having his girls, grandchildren, great-grandchildren and great-great-grandchildren with him. His church family was also very important to him.
Gerald is survived by his four daughters, Shirley McQuire, Lutz, Fla., Alda (Windy Hanson) Buxton, Viroqua, Geraldine (Loren) Anderson, Westby, Zelda (Norman) Morrison, Portage; 12 grandchildren; 26 great-grandchildren; 15 great-great-grandchildren; five stepgrandchildren; two stepgreat-grandchildren; nieces; nephews; other relatives; and friends.
He was preceded in death by his parents; wives, Alma in 1976, and Irene in 2004; daughter, Betty Carson, October, 2010; grandson, Clayton Hirschfield; two brothers; and two sisters.
Funeral services will be held at 11 a.m. on Tuesday, Dec. 28, at Viroqua Church of Christ. Officiating at the service will be Elder Larry Mosher with burial to follow in Liberty Pole Cemetery. The family will greet relatives and friends from 10 a.m. until the time of service at 11 a.m. on Tuesday, Dec. 28, at the church. Reetz-Thorson Funeral Home, Viroqua, is assisting the family with arrangements.
On line condolences may be offered on Gerald’s memorial page at www.reetzfh.com.

description.hltext_display: JYP is 5.8billion won in debt
고종이 하사한 땅에 서울 최초의 호텔을 세운 독일 여성
description.content:
호텔 근대적인 숙박시설이 등장하기 시작한 것은 1880년대 부산·원산·인천항이 개항되면서다. 1888년에 일본인 호리 리키타로씨가 인천 중구에 3층짜리 벽돌 양옥 '대불(大佛)호텔'을 지었다. 서양식 침실과 식당을 갖췄다고 한다. 당시 인천항을 통해 서울에 드나들던 유럽·미국인들이 주로 묵었다. 대불호텔 길 건너에서 상점을 하던 청나라 사람 이태(怡泰)가 대불호텔을 보고 자기 건물 2층에 '스튜어드(Steward)호텔'을 개업했다고 했을 정도로 영업은 잘됐다고 한다. 그러나 1899년 경인선 개설과 함께 불황을 타기 시작해 1918년 중국인에게 넘어가 '중화루'란 요릿집으로 간판이 바뀌었고, 1978년 6월에는 건물이 헐려 지금은 식당 주차장으로 쓰이고 있다. ▲ '대불(大佛)호텔' 1902년 독일 여성 손탁(Sontag)이 서울 정동에 세운 '손탁호텔'은 서울에 등장한 최초의 호텔이다. 주한 러시아공사 웨베르의 처제인 손탁은 조선 왕실과 친해 고종이 1895년 경운궁(慶運宮) 건너편에 있는 땅을 손탁에게 하사했다. 손탁은 1902년 10월 옛집을 헐고 2층짜리 서양식 건물을 지어 2층은 객실, 1층은 객실과 식당으로 사용했다. 1904년 3월과 1905년 11월에는 이토 히로부미(伊藤博文)가, 러일전쟁 때는 영국 총리가 되는 처칠(Churchill)이 묵기도 했다. 1917년 이화학당이 이 건물을 사들여 강의실, 기숙사 등으로 쓰다가 1922년 건물을 헐고 3층짜리 프라이 홀(Frey Hall)을 세웠다.
현존하는 한국 최고(最古)의 호텔은 1914년 조선총독부 산하 철도국이 서울 소공동에 건립한 '조선호텔', 현재의 웨스틴조선호텔이다. 독일 건축가 궤데란트의 설계로 약 1920㎡(580평) 건평에 지하 1층, 지상 4층으로 지어졌다. 52개의 객실과 한식당·양식당·커피숍·로비라운지·바·댄스홀·도서실을 갖췄고, 엘리베이터(일명 수직열차), 아이스크림, 뷔페식사, 댄스파티, 서구식 결혼식 등 신문화 도입이 이곳에서 이뤄졌다. 광복 후 소유권도 교통부로 넘어갔다가 1983년 민영화되었다. 1992년에는 삼성그룹에서 분리된 신세계가 조선호텔 주식을 인수해 운영하고 있다.

description.hltext_display: Strumpfuskare stängs av
description.author: webmaster@vt.se
description.content: Internationella taekwondoförbundets hemsida attackerades av hackare som var upprörda efter att taiwanesiskan Yang Shu-chun straffats med avstängning efter att ha haft för många sensorer i strumporna under Asiatiska spelen. Yang diskvalificerades under tävlingarna och stängs nu av i tre månader. Hennes tränare fick 20 månaders avstängning och Taiwans taekwondoförbund får böta motsvarande 341 000 kronor. TT-AFP

description.hltext_display: Embracing Australia
description.content: A survey of Australian attitudes towards immigration has found that although most people support multiculturalism, adapting to its challenges is a constant struggle.The research -- commissioned by SBS -- also reveals that although the nationalities of those arriving have changed over the years -- many concerns remain the same. A survey of 1,400 Australians conducted by the Ipsos-Eureka Social Research Institute found that 62 per cent agree that Australia should be a multicultural society. But only 48 per cent believe migrants should be able to maintain their culture without prejudice or disadvantage, and 23 percent of those from non-English speaking backgrounds say they experienced racial discrimination in the past year. "There were a lot of patterns around people thinking that people should embrace the Australian way of life and very much associated that with speaking the language," says researcher Caroline Tomiczek. Less sympathy for asylum-seekers The survey also found that sympathy for asylum-seekers has declined over the past decade. Yet eight out of 10 believe that Australia has been generous to immigrants throughout its history. Dr Tomiczek says that a comparison of surveys going back 25-years revealed a pattern of fear and anxiety about new arrivals. "And the things people were saying about Italians were quite similar to the things people said about Muslims," she says. Filmmaker, Alex West, says he also noticed this pattern in producing "Immigration Nation", an SBS documentary which investigates migration back to Federation including the controversial White Australia Policy. "The kind of fears that people had over 100 years ago are similar to what they had today, these kind of dark paranoias about invasion from the north that Asian hordes are going to overrun this country," says Alex West, the producer of SBS' Immigration Nation. From the slavery of South Sea Islanders to hostilities towards early Asian and European immigrants, Mr West says that Australia has forged a multicultural society against the odds. The Ipsos-Eureka survey appears to back that up, finding that within one generation, those with a migrant background show as strong a sense of belonging as the general Australian population. The three-part multi-platform documentary, will be screened on SBS One and online from January the 9th.

description.hltext_display: 2010 in Reivew
description.content:
Relatives of the Chilean miners - the world watched with them as all 33 men were winched to safety. (AAP) From the leak of top-secret US documents to disasters in Pakistan and Haiti, the usual international news agenda was tempered by good news from deep below the Chilean desert.Not long after the new year, reports of a major earthquake hitting an impoverished Caribbean island which had for years already dealt with civil conflict, IMF restructuring and annual devastating hurriances, reached foreign newsrooms.
Earthquake in Haiti On January 13, Port-au-Prince. The quake killed 220,000 people, left 1.3 million people homeless and destroyed countless buildings. Amid efforts to rebuild Haiti, the nation now faces a cholera endemic, which broke out in the weeks following the quake. Iraqi polls Around 200,000 police were on operation in Iraq for elections on March 7th. Representatives from Iraq's 74 political parties were fighting it out on Iraqi soil for the 325 seats and they still were come November, until former al-Maliki in a power-sharing deal. Thailand's Red Shirts Red Shirt Thai protesters on March 20 in one of many bids to force Prime Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva from office. The Red Shirts accused the PM of taking power through illegitimate means, calling for him to dissolve Parliament and call fresh elections- a demand he repeatedly rejected. The growth of WikiLeaks For many, the . Their mainstream presence grew when, on April 5, the site released Collateral Murder: a classified US military video depicting the killing of civilians in Baghdad by Apache helicopters. Following the Afghan War Logs, WikiLeaks began the publication of more than 250,000 US State Department cables in late November. Throughout December, the sideshow became the headline issue the continued pursuit of Assange on sex charges - and the backlash. Rajapakse cements power In April, the ruling party of Sri Lankan President Mahinda Rajapakse , after defeating the Tamil Tigers. Turnout was at a record low, and proposed changes to the constitution later in the year had many critics claiming a slide to autocracy. Iceland's Eyjafjallajoekull Throughout April, an News of Europes flight troubles sent every other international story to the bottom of the agenda as journalists around the world struggled to pronounce Eyjafjallajoekull. Poland mourns The President of Poland, Lech Kaczynski, was among 97 passengers, including many dignitaries, after the plane hit trees approaching Smolenski airport in thick fog. Channelling a shocked country, Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk said the crash was the most tragic event of the countrys post-World War II history. BP's Gulf oil spill On April 20, when an explosion off the Gulf of Mexico sank the Deepwater Horizon Rig, killing eleven people and leading to the worst oil spill in U.S history. A team of investigators narrowed the disaster down to a complex and interlinked series of mechanical failures, human judgement and engineering design. Pope sorry for abuse In May, the Pope took the hitherto unprecedented step of in a letter. This followed a growing sex abuse scandal across European parishes, including his native Germany. But many victims said the apology went nowhere near far enough. UK gets historic coalition The British election led to the first hung parliament in the UK since 1974, with the Conservative Party unable to take an overall majority. On May 12, David Cameron after the Liberal Democrats shocked even their own voters by siding with the centre-right party, instead of the then-governing Labor party. Bailouts and EU unrest In May, from the EU and IMF. This led to strict austerity measures and subsequent civil rest across the country over the year. Later, international financers agreed to pump At the end of the year, markets still showed concern that the other PIIGS Portugal, Italy, Ireland, Greece and Spain - may still be teetering on the verge of financial disaster.
Kyrgyzstan unrest
Deadly ethnic clashes rocked the central Asian state of Kyrgyzstan in June. Up to 2000 people were killed, and up to a million were affected. Uzbek victims of violence claim there was a McChrystal steps down On 23rd June, a red-faced Stanley McChrystal was following an interview with Rolling Stone magazine. In the piece, a candid McChrystal laid in to the governments handling of the war, and called the presidents national security advisor a clown. Pakistan's devastating floods Pakistan was pushed to the brink as the worst floods in years swept through the country in July and August. . Amid claims of the world turning its back, some international observers pointed the finger at Pakistani authorities mismanaging aid donations. From either side, the magnitude of the floods, and the sheer numbers affected, hit home to viewers around the world. Chilean miners after the entrance to the mine collapsed on August 5. As their families waited for news of their loved ones, global interest mushroomed when it was reported that, unexpectedly, the men were still alive. Their time underground exceeded the record of 25 days, logged by Chinese miners in 2009 becoming the feel-good story of the year when the men finally emerged into the spotlight. The model and the 'Blood Diamond' Supermodel Naomi Campbell was summoned to an international war tribunal to testify over blood diamonds she was allegedly given by former Liberian president Charles Taylor. Taylor was on trial for his alleged role in orchestrating the war in Sierra Leone, accused of using illegally mined diamonds to fund arms used by the Revolutionary United Front. A slightly annoyed looking and didnt know their value. Philippines hostage crisis In August, pictures of a tourist bus and its passengers shocked TV audiences around the world. Local police defended their handling of the operation, which left eight Hong Kong tourists dead. Iraq pull-out On August 31, the US - at least on the surface. Fourty-nine thousand troops will remain in Iraq until their scheduled departure by the end of 2011. President Obama praised the militarys efforts and said they had met their responsibility yet Iraq remains unhinged by insurgent violence and political instability. Ground Zero Mosque Koran Burning A radical Florida pastor threatened to - an act world leaders feared would have sparked a fierce global backlash. US Defence Secretary Robert Gates made a personal phone call to persuade Reverend Terry Jones to change his mind, warning the act would put US soldiers' lives at risk. Jones later abandoned his plan. Barack Obama supported the right to build the mosque and said Muslims "have the right to practise their religion as anyone else in this country". Aung San Suu Kyi released Burmas democracy leader Aung San Suu Kyi . The Nobel Peace Prize winner, renowned for her long fight for democracy, was freed just days after an election which was slammed internationally, despite being praised in some quarters for taking tentative steps towards reform. NZ miners perish Two Australians were following a methane explosion on November 19. A series of explosions during the following week killed all of the men in an event that tested the small, close-knit community. And around the world, the shock that this would not be another Chilean miners scenario took time to settle in. Soaring Mexican drug killings Drug-gang violence soured to unprecedented levels across Mexico, with thousands of people killed in the unrelenting slaughter. In September, US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton said that - a charge Mexico rejected. Insulting war crimes report At the start of October, a long-awaited UN report into war crimes in the CR Congo including Rwanda, who said accusations that troops killed and raped Hutu refugees in the DR Congo following the Rwandan genocide were an insult to history Xiaobo wins Nobel Prize Jailed Chinese dissident Liu Xiaobo for his "long and non-violent struggle for fundamental human rights". The move angered Beijing, which jailed 54-year-old Liu for 11 years for subversion. The author and former professor was at the forefront of the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests. Indonesian disasters Hundreds of people were killed as entire villages were swept away following a tsunami off the Indonesian island of Sumatra in late October. killing locals and burying villages in ash. Rise of the Tea Party sees Democrats trounced US mid-term elections saw Barack Obamas , losing control in the House of Reps but just hanging on to the Senate. While push factors from the economy to health reform sent votes to the Republicans, the pull factor was for many the irresistible conservatism of the Tea Party a new force in American politics had arrived. Koreas on war footing
Tensions on the Korean peninsula took a major turn for the worse when , killing one and injuring over a dozen, citing provocation. A month later, following army drills and international haggling over who should condone who, the situation remained tense. Somalia Piracy On November 14, Somali pirates for more than one year after seizing the retired couple from their yacht in the Indian Ocean. Somali pirates capture dozens of vessels each year, and the country remains unhinged by years of fighting between rival warlords. Somalia's inability to deal with famine and disease has been heightened by the lack of effective government, leading to the death of millions.
Cambodain stampede
A stampede in the Cambodian capital Phnom Penh when panic erupted at the annual water festival. Commentators said it was the biggest tragedy to hit the nation since the days of the Khmer Rouge. Ivory Coast unrest The Ivory Coast was as post-election violence killed at least 50 people and injured hundreds more. The November 28 elections were supposed to stabilise the country- once one of West Africa's most prosperous. Both incumbent leader Gbagbo, and his rival, Alassane Quattara, claim to have won the election. The international community recognised Quattara as the winner, but Gbagbo won't give up power, and more violence loomed at the time of wrting.

description.hltext_display: Namibia: Annual Vasbyt at Dune 7
description.content:
HOLIDAYMAKERS at the coast can look forward to the 4x4 Vasbyt competition that will be held on December 29 at the renowned Dune 7.
This is the 12th consecutive year that the event is being held and it only goes from strength to strength.
Traditionally, participants compete over 10 obstacles but to make it more interesting this year the organisers have added bonus obstacles and an open category for 4x4 owners.
Elmarie Cilliers of WesBank said: "We are very proud to be associated with this spectacular event. We hope to increase on the over 8 000 spectators of last year. Vasbyt events have become a popular spectator sport and our vision is to expand on this growth with our sponsorship."
So far, 22 vehicles have entered in the competition, of which two are from South Africa.
Gates will open at 09h00 and the event will start at 11h00.

description.hltext_display: 입술 보호제 '비판톨' 직접 써보니…
description.content:
입술은 우리 몸에서 가장 주름이 많고 민감한 부위다. 그래서 건조한 겨울철 쉽게 트고 갈라진다. 립밤, 립크림 등 시중에서 판매하는 입술 보호제만 해도 수백 가지. 가격도 종류도 천차만별이다. 이 가운데 냄새 없고 저자극이라는 이유로 마니아층 사이에서 입소문이 난 바이엘의 입술보호제 '비판톨'을 일반인들이 체험해 봤다. 성인 남녀 15명(남자 5명, 여자 10명)이 이 제품을 사용한 뒤 설문에 응답했다.
체험 결과 이 제품의 가장 큰 장점은 유분감이 적어 끈적거리지 않는다는 점이었다. "끈적거리거나 번들거렸느냐"는 질문에 응답자 중 8명이 "별로 끈적이지 않았다", 4명이 "전혀 끈적이지 않았다"고 답했다. 이 때문에 입술에 크림 바르는 걸 불편해하는 남자들에게 반응이 좋았다. 한 남성 체험자는 "끈적이지 않고 번들거리지 않아 남자가 쓰기에 부담스럽지 않다"고 말했다. 무색, 무향도 강점. "향이 없어 거부감이 작다", "쓸데없는 맛이 없어 편하다"는 반응이 많았지만, "연고 같은 느낌"이라는 반응도 있었다.
흡수력과 피부 재생력은 보통을 약간 선회하는 수준. 흡수력을 묻는 "사용 후 입술이 촉촉해졌냐"는 질문에는 별 4개를 준 응답자가 8명, 별 3개를 준 응답자가 6명이었으며 1명이 별 2개를 줬다. 평균 별점은 3.5개. "갈라지거나 찢어진 입술이 나았느냐"는 항목에는 별 4개가 7명, 별 3개가 5명, 별 2개가 3명이었다. 평균 별점은 3.3개.
튜브형으로 짜서 쓰는 타입에는 불만이 많았다. "크림이 나오는 구멍이 작아 입술에 맞춰 바르기가 쉽지 않다", "양 조절하기가 쉽지 않다"는 부정적인 반응이 주를 이뤘다.
이 제품의 가격은 5000원. 가격 대비 만족도를 묻는 말에는 "매우 만족한다" "대체로 만족한다" "보통" "별로 만족하지 않는다" "전혀 만족하지 않는다" 중 "대체로 만족한다"가 6명, "별로 만족하지 않는다"가 5명, "보통"이 3명이었다.

description.hltext_display: New low-cost mammography center to host open house
description.author: Special to The Union
description.content:
Insight Imaging Inc., a new mammogram clinic in Grass Valley, will host an open house and ribbon cutting from 5 to 6:30 p.m. today at 140 Litton Drive, Suite 208.
The facility provides low-cost mammograms, general and vascular ultra-sound, and bone density studies.
Insight Imaging offers screening mammograms — recommended annually for all women over 40 — for $250, instead of the usual $450 to $500 cost. Self-pay patients without insurance receive a 30 percent discount.
“Our research revealed that one-third of western Nevada County women travel to Auburn or Sacramento for mammograms because the procedure is less expensive there,” said Dr. Melisa Agness, the diagnostic radiologist at Insight Imaging. “There is more at stake than local dollars flowing out of the county.
“If a woman who received her mammogram in Auburn or Sacramento needs a post-mammogram biopsy or surgery, she frequently travels back ‘down the hill' for follow-up care,” Agness added. “At our center, she can now receive low-cost mammography services, and if follow-up care is needed, she can be referred locally to Sierra Nevada Memorial Hospital instead of a hospital 30 to 60 miles away.”
Insight Imaging is committed to serving the needs of all women, especially those who lack insurance, are under-insured or who have high-deductible health plans. Insight Imaging has donated 10 free screening mammograms to five local nonprofit organizations, including as Women of Worth.
In addition, Insight Imaging offered free mammograms to its first 28 patients when it opened last week.
Screening mammograms do not require a physician's orders, and Insight Imaging accepts all insurance, including Medi-Cal.
In fewer than one out of 10 cases, a screening mammogram will reveal a mass or other issue that requires a more in-depth diagnostic mammogram.
Agness plans to share screening and diagnostic information immediately with patients to relieve potential anxiety, in addition to sending the mandated letters. She has designed the clinic's workday schedule so she can discuss and review results with patients either immediately following the exam or by telephone within 24 to 48 hours after the exam. Patients can view their images and ask questions or schedule a return visit.
Insight Imaging serves patients from 8 a.m. to 5:430 p.m. Monday through Friday, and every other Saturday morning. Later appointments can be arranged.
Insight Imaging can be reached at (530) 277-1460 or 273-2720.

event_or_fact.property: ?Our research revealed that one-third of western Nevada County women travel to Auburn or Sacramento for mammograms because the procedure is less expensive there,?

description.hltext_display: "김대리 센스 있네" 귀에 속속 들어오는 연말 건배사
description.content:
카피라이터가 추천한 연말 '센스 건배사' 11 "자, 이제 돌아가면서 건배사 한마디씩 할까?"
망년회 자리, 피할 수 없는 통과의례인 건배사. 한 치 혀로 천당과 지옥을 왔다 갈 수 있다. 달아오른 분위기에 찬물을 끼얹어 공공의 적이 될 것인가, 축 처진 자리에 활력을 불어넣어 모임의 꽃으로 등극할 것인가. 고민 해결을 위해 스마트폰용 건배사 앱까지 등장할 정도다. 홈&라이프팀이 유명 카피라이터인 광고대행사 오리콤 캠페인본부 손수진 차장의 도움을 얻어 올 연말 송년회에서 주목받을 수 있는 건배사 11개를 추천한다. 모임의 성격을 따져 아래 11개를 적당히 활용하면 술자리 분위기 깨는 '아이스맨'은 모면할 수 있다.
아저씨 : 아자 아자! 저무는 한 해는 잊고 다시 시작하자!
(올해 인기를 끌었던 동명의 영화 '아저씨' 패러디)
노총각 : 노(No)하지 말고 총대 메고 각 세우지 말고…!
(비굴 버전으로)
토끼웰컴 : 토 나오지 않고 끼만 가득한 웰빙할 수 있는 컴퍼니(회사)를 위하여! (토끼해를 맞아)
토사구팽 : 내년 토끼를 잘 사역해서 개도 팽팽해지는 잘 사는 신묘년을 위하여! (토끼도 살고 개도 살고)
너나잘해 : 너와 나의 잘나가는 새해를 위하여!
아이유 : 아이러브유, 유러브미!
(인기 가수 아이유의 이름을 활용해)
탱탱탱 : 탱탱한 피부와 탱탱한 삶과 탱탱한 내일을 위하여!
고고고 : 내년에 더욱 잘나가고, 잘 먹고, 끝까지 살고!
(잘나가고, 잘 먹고, 살고. 말할 때 '고'에서 악센트 주기!)
비둘기 : 비장하게 둘러 모여 기차게 즐기자!
삼식이와 삼순이 : (대한민국) 삼삼하고 식상(순수)하지 않은(한) 이 세상(이뿐이)을 위해서!
러브 앤 피스: 긴장이 고조되고 있는 대한민국 그리고 가정의 평화를 위해!

description.hltext_display: Confusion reigns over cough, cold meds
description.author: Sue Hubbard
description.content:
The confusion over cough and cold medications continues, and I must admit I?m a little confused, too.
The Consumer Healthcare Products Association has announced changes to the labelling of over-the-counter (OTC) cold products to state ?do not use in children under four years of age.? The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) monograph still states, ?do not use in children under two years.? The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends not using OTC cough and cold preparations in children under six years old.
Looking at the little research on these products, two things come to mind:
1. There have been multiple studies done on these products (in adults) that do not show them to be efficacious for treating common cough and cold symptoms.
2. The research among children using these products shows that dosing errors and accidental ingestions are the leading cause of adverse events.
This kind of leaves me thinking, why use them at all in children? I?ve never been much of a cold medicine giver in general, as I personally did not see my own children getting better any faster by using such products.
We continued to use the good old grandmother-tested remedies, like: lots of rest, freshly-squeezed orange juice (sometimes it pays to be sick), chicken noodle soup (canned or homemade), and a vapourizer or humidifier in their rooms at night.
I also know that younger children get more colds than anyone else. But miraculously, as kids get older, they get fewer colds and seem to tolerate them a little better.
So, for this winter, in our practice we?re not recommending the use of any cold products for kids and trying the gold standards: rest, fluids, cool mist humidifier and tincture of time. We?ll see how it goes. Dr. Sue Hubbard is a nationally known pediatrician and co-host of ?The Kid?s Doctor? radio show. Submit questions at www.kidsdr.com.
(c) 2010, KIDSDR.COM DISTRIBUTED BY TRIBUNE MEDIA SERVICES, INC.

description.hltext_display: Plans for CNG crematorium in pet cemetery
description.content:
The Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC) has decided to make budgetary provision for a compressed natural gas (CNG) crematorium in its pet cemetery located in Nehrunagar, Pimpri.
PCMC veterinary department head, Dr Satish Gore, told DNA on Tuesday, We are planning a CNG crematorium as it is cheaper than LPG. The expenditure for the project is around Rs25 lakh. A proposal will be tabled in the standing committee. According to civic officials, it will not only speed up the disposal of animal carcasses, but also save space.
At present, the cemetery is nearly full. Over the last three years, it has witnessed as many as 1,080 burials at the rate of approximately one animal per day.
Gore added that the new CNG crematorium willdispose of the body in three to four hours and will also save space.

description.hltext_display: COAI releases 2nd Edition of the Kindle™ Best Seller “Inside the Giant...
description.content:
"Inside the Giant Machine - An Amazon.com Story" Special Low Price on Kindle
"Kindle platform's flexibility has allowed us to rapidly add new content in response to feedback" said Kalpanik S., author of the Kindle bestseller 'Inside the Giant Machine - An Amazon.com Story', "and release the 2nd edition in less than 10 months"
- Center of Artificial Imagination has just released the 2nd edition of the best-selling Kindle™ Book “Inside the Giant Machine: An Amazon.com Story,” by Kalpanik S. This edition includes five new chapters, giving further details of Amazon's transformation from a retailer to a marketplace which enabled it to surpass its long time Nemesis, eBay, in profits. The author, a former Amazon.com technologist conitue to use humor and his sharp wit to make his description of the inner workings of Amazon.com interesting as he explains how Amazon learned from its e-commerce nemesis, eBay and leveraged its own unique advantages to launch a eCommerce platform leading to its supremacy in both the online retail and online marketplace segments,
Intermixed with the main story, we also get a glimpse of his yearning for acceptance as an immigrant, his adjustment to and acceptance of midlife, and his struggle as a technologist to find harmony in the chaos of the Internet revolution.
In this greatly expanded 2nd edition which was released earlier today on Kindle(tm), Kalpanik adds more details to his hilarious-yet-touching personal story - how, after leaving behind their home and their friends in Silicon Valley and moving to Seattle to work for Amazon and found himself facing the double whammy of having to cope with both the drastically different Northwest climate and Amazon’s unusual work environment. The newly added chapters on Amazon's transformation to a marketplace and its foray in the work of digital publishing, continue to have the fish-out-of-water humor. wisdom and a touch of philosophy. Finally, the author has added two bonus chapters at the end of the book, where he describes his experiences in self-publishing the first edition of the book on Kindle™ and how he used that knowledge to improve the 2nd edition.
“After reviewing feedback from readers for the first edition, we decided to a follow up edition with additional material in the areas where the readers felt that the book fell short." said Kalpanik S. who authored the book. "Kindle platform's flexibility has allowed us to rapidly add new content in response to feedback and release the 2nd edition in less than 10 months. In addition, because of the digital nature of the distribution of Kindle™ content, we did not have to worry about inventory obsolescence which is a major issue while revising printed books. I believe that the additional details included in this newly released 2nd edition further accentuate the story of my unique experiences expressed in my distinctive voice, making this book an entertaining and enjoyable read for everyone.”
To celebrate today's release of the 2nd edition, the publisher, Center of Artificial Imagination, is offering the book on Kindle™ for a special low price till a limited time.
Trademark and Other Notices
Kindle™ and Amazon are registered trademarks of Amazon.com. eBay is a registered trademark of eBay. Even though this book about Amazon and Kindle™ is published using Amazon’s digital publishing services (also called the Kindle™ publishing network), this book, like all other books published on Kindle™, is not officially endorsed in any way by Amazon’s Kindle™ group.

description.hltext_display: Road rage doctor could lose sports car
description.content:
A Perth doctor convicted of road rage will soon learn whether his Alfa Romeo sports car will be permanently confiscated when a magistrate hands down his landmark verdict.Police want to seize the car belonging to Ala'A Mohammed Ali Al Rammahi who earlier this year pleaded guilty to reckless driving and was fined.
Angry a woman had beeped her horn at him, Al Rammahi followed and repeatedly pulled in front of her car, traumatising her and her children.
Police are using a 2007 amendment to anti-hoon confiscation legislation that allows for vehicles to be seized for road rage offences.
Al Rammahi, who owns two medical practices, is fighting the application, claiming he would suffer severe financial hardship if he lost his car, valued at between $17,000 and $20,000.
In the Perth Magistrates Court on Wednesday, Al Rammahi's lawyer Max Crispe questioned the validity of the application.
He argued police technically erred by failing to give his client notice and issued the application without authority.
Prosecutor Mike Crook said the application should not be dismissed because it was made "in the spirit" of the legislation.
Magistrate Guiseppe Cicchini said the case could be the first of its kind and queries over errors with the application had to be resolved.
The court heard that the doctor had financial problems, including a defaulted loan on a multi-million dollar home. He also still owes about $6000 on his car.
Mr Crook asked Al Rammahi how he expected to make repayments on his car because he had failed to make the past two.
"I have not paid but (that) doesn't mean that I can't pay," he said.
When pressed further, Al Rammahi snapped: "Do you think I'm lying for $17,000?"
In his closing submissions, Mr Crispe said his client unlikely to re-offend.
Magistrate Cicchini said he would have to consider the doctor's financial and physical hardship, and other relevant factors including the seriousness of the offence, before making his decision on Thursday.

description.hltext_display: Rogers 'gripped by terror' on boat ride
description.content:
Dual international Mat Rogers was "gripped by terror" as a Gold Coast boat cruise with former rugby league team-mates and friends almost ended in tragedy at the weekend.Rogers was one of 10 people, including two children, on a 10-metre boat with former Titans team-mate Greg Bird, TV personality Matt Johns and international cyclist Robbie McEwen, when passengers began losing consciousness after inhaling undetectable carbon monoxide fumes.
He and McEwen are being hailed as heroes after rescuing a passenger who fell overboard during the drama.
"There was a time on the boat I felt terrified and powerless to do anything," the recently retired NRL star told AAP on Wednesday.
"I was pretty messed up for a time. I slipped off my chair and ended up on the ground but I don't think I lost complete consciousness.
"It was frightening.
"I was standing there thinking 'what's happening, what's happening' it was like something out of a movie.
"I remember I had my phone in my hand and I was looking at it wondering what I was going to do with it, I couldn't even make a phone call."
Despite his confused state, Rogers leapt into the water to help a man who'd fallen off the back of the boat after blacking out just off Sanctuary Cove.
He and McEwen, whose high altitude training and superior oxygen levels helped him cope with the situation better than other passengers, kept the unconscious passenger's head above water until help arrived.
"I saw the man walk around to the back of the boat and pass out and fall into the water," recalled the 34 year-old Rogers.
"I think I was probably the only one who saw him fall overboard. I was just coming to my senses and jumped in which was probably a silly thing to do.
"I ran through the boat and just dived in. Robbie (McEwen) tried to stop me because he knew I wasn't any good and then he dived in after me.
"I just grabbed the guy and laid back in the water and waited for the boat to come back around and get us."
The scary experience left Rogers more exhausted than in any of the 100 representative games he played during his career.
"I was that spent. I had no oxygen left in my system after I'd jumped in with Robbie to get this guy, I couldn't get back in the boat," he said.
"Luckily Birdie (Greg Bird) realised how serious it was and he just grabbed me and pulled me into the boat.
"I'm glad Birdie was there, he's a big fella and I was really struggling."
The drama started on the slow trip back from McLaren's Landing when passengers began to lose consciousness.
The plastic panels on the side of the boat, lowered to protect passengers from a storm, had created a vacuum that sucked the killer fumes back into the boat.
"We were breathing it in, totally oblivious to it, we couldn't smell it," said Rogers.
"It was nobody's fault, it was just one of those freak things."

event_or_fact.property: I had no oxygen left in my system after I'd jumped in with Robbie to get this guy, I couldn't get back in the boat
We were breathing it in, totally oblivious to it, we couldn't smell it

description.hltext_display: Oakeshott joins MRRT critics
description.content:
Independent MP Rob Oakeshott has joined in the chorus of attacks on the federal government's handling of its proposed mining tax.Mr Oakeshott said the government should release the final details of its minerals resource rent tax (MRRT) as soon as parliament resumes in February.
The policy transition group released its report on the MRRT on Tuesday and recommended crediting all future state and territory royalties against the new tax.
That contradicted the government's stance of limiting credits to the level royalties were at in May 2010.
The resources industry has largely welcomed the group's report but Queensland Premier Anna Bligh and her WA counterpart Colin Barnett have been vocal in their opposition to any possibility of capping royalties.
Mr Oakeshott said there were too many handshakes happening behind closed doors.
"I think there's some cute politics being played behind closed doors ... (we need) a full-on public debate with a detailed piece of legislation," he told Sky News on Wednesday.
Ms Bligh and Mr Barnett have said their states have no plans to hike up royalties but they reserve the right to do so.
Ms Bligh toughened her stance on the suggestion that states should limit increases in royalties.
"There is a very important principle at stake," she told reporters in Brisbane.
"That principle is as fundamental as the ability of an elected state government to raise its own revenue to fund schools and hospitals and services.
"We are not going to give that away."
Mr Barnett said the WA government and other state governments would always collect royalties, which were set based on the value of the minerals.
"If the commonwealth wants to introduce a new tax, there may be a constitutional doubt about that, but if they want to do it, then they have to defend their tax on its grounds, not by attacking state royalties," he told Sky News.
The WA government did not propose to increase royalties but may be forced to as the federal government took more of its GST earnings away, Mr Barnett said.
"If the commonwealth continues to reduce the state's share of GST revenues, as is happening through the grants commission, a future West Australian government may have no choice but to increase royalties simply to maintain health, education, law and order services."
It was completely illogical for the federal government to say mining companies did not pay enough tax but would seek to stop states from raising royalties in the future, Mr Barnett said.
"It makes no sense to me...," he said.
Opposition frontbencher Bruce Billson says the recommendation represents an "enormous rebuke" for Prime Minister Julia Gillard and her policy.
"This was the mining tax that was so flawed Labor needed to take out a prime minister to fix it," he told Sky News, referring to Kevin Rudd.
"I wonder whether Julia Gillard's going to be taken out ... neither (prime minister) has got it right."
Labor MP David Bradbury denied a policy retreat, saying the report highlights "consensus emerging between industry and the government".

This was the mining tax that was so flawed Labor needed to take out a prime minister to fix it

description.hltext_display: Galaxy's Donovan staying home during offseason
description.content:
CARSON - The Galaxy's Landon Donovan is staying put and forgoing the chance to be loaned to a European club for the third consecutive winter.
Donovan scored two goals in 13 matches during a loan to Everton from last January to March, and Everton manager David Moyes appeared open to having the 28-year-old return.
"While I enjoyed my time at Everton last season and still appreciate all the support their fans have given me, I feel that it is important to continue to rest and recover this offseason as opposed to going on loan," Donovan said in a statement Tuesday.
"I never considered being loaned to a club other than Everton, but I have been playing nearly nonstop for the past two years and I believe that this decision will allow me to perform at my best for the Galaxy and the national team throughout the upcoming year."
Donovan said during last month's MLS playoffs that overcoming mental fatigue was more challenging than dealing with the physical. Despite missing time for the World Cup, Donovan scored seven goals for the Galaxy and led MLS with 16 assists.
Also ...
Galaxy defenders A.J. DeLaGarza, Sean Franklin and Omar Gonzalez were selected for a U.S. national team training camp ahead of the Americans' exhibition against Chile. Six of the 24 players on the roster announced for the
Jan. 22 game in Carson have played just one game for the national team. Orebro midfielder Alejandro Bedoya is the senior player
on the roster with six international appearances. ... Houston Dynamo goalkeeper Pat Onstad, 42, retired to take an assistant coaching job at D.C United. He was the league's all-time leader in goals against average (1.12) among goalkeepers with at least 10,000 minutes and third overall.

event_or_fact.property: While I enjoyed my time at Everton last season and still appreciate all the support their fans have given me, I feel that it is important to continue to rest and recover this offseason as opposed to going on loan; I never considered being loaned to a club
overcoming mental fatigue was more challenging than dealing with the physical.

description.hltext_display: Usmanov could make �700m offer for Arsenal
description.author: Jonathan Chong
description.content:
Russian-based businessman Alisher Usmanov has hinted that he may yet make a formal bid for the club, which is currently valued close to £700 million.
The Uzbek reignited takeover talk for the North London club when he signalled his intention to raise his stake in the club to 29.9 per cent, the minimum required to launch a formal takeover bid.
Usmanov already owns almost 27 per cent of the club. Raising it to 29.9 per cent would bring him on par with director Stan Kroenke, making both of them the largest individual shareholders in the club.
Usmanov said: "The goal is to increase the holding up to a blocking stake, 29.9 per cent.
"Afterwards, we'll see what to do further. If all the shareholders are united by then like they are now, we'll keep it as that level.
"I chose to invest significant money in Arsenal because I consider it to be one the world's most well-structured football clubs, with one of the best stadiums and led by a genius coach, Arsène Wenger.
"I don't regret this investment. It's not dropping in value, it's rising only."
In fact, Usmanov already enjoyed veto rights when he passed the 25 per cent mark, but taking himself to 29.9 per cent would provide him with more votes and also allow him to launch a formal bid for the club.
The latest shares traded changed hands last week for £11,200, making the club worth £692 million.

event_or_fact.property: The goal is to increase the holding up to a blocking stake, 29.9 per cent.
he may yet make a formal bid for the club, which is currently valued close to 700 million.

description.hltext_display: Personal Property Loan
description.content: It can be commonly seen that you require instant money to fulfill your requirements and needs. Personal property loan can be beneficial at that time, when you are in need of a loan to accomplish few important tasks. Personal property loan is a secured loan and it can be easily availed by pledging your immovable property like your home or land as collateral.Property loans are secured against a property. Property put as collateral can be a residential or a commercial property. The loan providers grant more flexibility to the borrower and freedom to use the money as they wish. A borrower can use a property loan to buy a new car or to pay for much needed home improvements.A personal bridging loan works as a monetary bridge to cover up the financial gap during property transaction. This loan is considered as a secured loan. Therefore, you have to pledge some thing in order to get the loan. Usually, borrowers use their new purchasing property as security. Besides, you can use some other properties like, housing or auction properties, commercial properties, retailing shops, overseas property etc.Personal bridging loans are approved against any valuable property of the borrower. Even the property to be sold or property to be bought can serve the purpose of collateral. On the basis of equity in collateral, the lenders approve a loan amount as personal bridging loan. Though it is secured loan, still, lenders charge higher interest rate on personal bridging loans. This is because personal bridging loans are short term loan. The lender usually is able to sell old property within some days or months.Personal bridging loan is essentially secured loan. There is usually huge amount of the lender at stake in offering the loan and so lender would like to have your old home or any valuable property as security. The loan amount as personal bridging loan depends on value of the property as collateral. Usually the borrower is approved almost all the amount required to buy new property like a home. However take note that despite being a secured loan, lenders will charge higher interest rate on personal bridging loan. This is mainly because personal bridging loan is short term loan.Personal bridging loan bridges the cash flow gap occurring between the buy of a new property and sale of the old one. However, personal bridging loan is a secured loan by nature. You are required to pledge your home as the collateral for personal bridging loan and take the money for a short period. However, there is open ended personal bridging loan and closed personal bridging loan. Open ended personal bridging loan means the kind of loan where the sale of your current property is yet to be done while closed ended personal bridging loan dent that the sale of your current property and buy of the new one has already been finalized.Personal bridging loan is a secured short term loan that is borrowed for duration of 1-12 months. It requires the older property of the borrower as collateral for the loan. During the term of the loan, only the interest has to be paid, and the principal amount has to be repaid when the property is sold off.

description.hltext_display: Therese Rein stuck in snowy London
description.content:
Foreign Minister Kevin Rudd's wife Therese Rein is one of thousands of stranded commuters held up by icy conditions in London and at risk of missing Christmas at home.Mr Rudd said his wife was expected home on Thursday but with flights cancelled after big snowfalls in England's capital forcing flight cancellations, she is trying to find an alternative way home.
Asked by reporters in Sydney why she was stuck in London, the foreign minister replied: "Snow, it's the white stuff, comes out of the sky, goes phoom like that".
But, Mr Rudd said, her presents would be under the tree when she did return.
"So, I've told her we're just going to defer Christmas in case she doesn't make it," he said.
"We'll make sure that her Santa stocking is preserved.
"But for all those Australians who are stuck at the moment, either trying to get there or trying to get out, it's a tough and rough time at the moment.
"And so, hopefully, the weather will clear and, hopefully, we can get people home soon, including Therese."
Cancellations have stranded thousands of travellers, affecting flights internationally - and the big freeze is tipped to continue.

Snow, it's the white stuff, comes out of the sky, goes phoom like that

description.hltext_display: Shoppers spending more, but only just
description.content:
Shoppers are expected to spend more money in Queensland leading up to Christmas than they did last year, but only just, the Australian Retailers Association (ARA) says.The peak industry body has projected that for Queensland from the last two weeks of November through to Christmas Eve consumers will spend $8.2 billion of the $39.9 billion it expects to be spent across the country.
But that is not a big increase, up from $8.1 billion over the same period last year.
ARA executive director Russell Zimmerman said retailers were hoping that having five full weekdays of shopping before Christmas would give retailers a slight advantage. "It is going to be a very ordinary Christmas with a techno twist," Mr Zimmerman told AAP.
He said goods like iPads and iPhones were selling well, but some of the normally popular items at Christmas like small electrical goods and packaged perfumes had already gone on sale because they were not selling well. "Clothes are also doing poorly, mainly because of the weather, with people reluctant to buy when it has been wet and cooler than normal," Mr Zimmerman said. He said the tourist areas of Queensland like the Gold Coast would also be hit hard because of the drop in the number of visitors spending their money.
Mr Zimmerman said there were a number of reasons for the sluggish pre-Christmas sales.
He said the wet and cooler than normal weather and the Melbourne Cup Day interest rate rise when banks almost doubled the Reserve Bank increase were two of the main ones. "It was just like someone turned the tap off," Mr Zimmerman said. He said figures released on Tuesday by Fitch Ratings showed in Queensland there had been a significant increase in the number of people in arrears on their mortgage payments and that also had to be a factor.
The aftermath of the global financial crisis and the big increases in electricity and water bills were also having an impact, Mr Zimmerman said.
However, despite hopingconsumers would keep on spending over the final two days before Christmas, Mr Zimmerman also adopted a cautious approach and urged people to "spend wisely".

description.hltext_display: Cutting-edge visionary propels Korean design
description.content:
By Ines Min
Like the vibrant punch of color on her silk scarf, Choi Jung-sim has a surprising vision for the future of traditional Korean crafts: modernization.
While the final month of 2010 has been inundated with design events, festivals and expos, one hosting organization has stood out from the rushed crowds: the Korean Craft & Design Foundation (KCDF).
Foundation director Choi, 48, sat down with The Korea Times Tuesday at the KCDF Gallery in Anguk-dong, in central Seoul, to detail her plans, projects and prospects. From top: A set of mirrors made from pieces found at a “hanok,” traditional Korean house, by Lee Ja-hee; abandoned chairs refurbished by Jung Jae-bum and Kim Ha-yan; Choi Jung-sim, director of the Korea Craft & Design Foundation
/ Courtesy of KCDF The recently transformed KCDF was integrated with the Korea Design Foundation in April, and is now an affiliate of the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism. While the past has seen numerous organizations striving to keep up established practices in traditional Korean crafts, Choi spearheads her campaign for change with a fundamental difference.
Pushing away the strict definitions of “traditional Korean crafts,” the director liberates the modern design fields of Korea.
“The things we make today, won’t they be relics tomorrow? Tomorrow it will be tradition. Everything is passed down from moment, to moment, to moment,” Choi said. “Tradition is the memories of the things that we loved.”
Bridging the gap between antiquated and contemporary, the director works under the fact that Korean craftwork ? from “hanok” (housing) to furniture ? is simply industrial design. And modern, local concepts need tweaking.
“The design we’re aware of is mostly the factory-made, mass-manufactured design of an industrialized society. Although it’s not everything, it’s how most industrial design is made,” she said. “So it’s those simple designs of manufactured goods that are in demand.”
Unfortunately, while the talent and resources are there, a creative approach to spur the field seems to be lacking. Choi hopes to bring that Korean sense back into domestic products.
“When we look at crafts, we meet a 5,000-year history. But because the history of industrial design isn’t that long, it has been Western culture ? and in particular Europe ? that has really influenced our mentality, led us and played a pivotal role,” said Choi, who is also a professor at Kaywon School of Art and Design in Gyeonggi Province.
“So I think it has been difficult to find our design, our identity.”
Choi hopes to preserve tradition through an exposure of Korean culture from youth, such as in modern children’s literature (the tales of Hans Christian Andersen dominated the images of her youth) and other creative outlets. While Korea is well known for its sports stars, films and even contemporary art, industrial design is still sorely underdeveloped.
And, as iconic designers before her, Choi can’t turn away from the downfalls of mass production. While convenience is an advantage, unsustainable design merely burdens the environment.
“If we turn our attention to handicrafts, there we can find an alternative that solves all the problems of mass production,” she said.
The 6th annual Design Made 2010 executes the idea that today’s consumer products can be recreated using recycled materials with Korean flair. The three-part showcase is taking place at the KCDF Gallery, Lotte Gallery at Avenuel and the recently closed 2010 Public Design Expo at Coex.
While the gallery holds the archival pieces of the exhibit (the process of refurbishing a chair is seen in three parts), the expo saw the participation of university students studying design. Lotte Gallery, however, is the gem of the showcase.
Cleverly situated floors above one of the city’s most well-known department stores, “up-cycled” goods are given new life. A broken down chair from Suncheon Elementary School is given a paint and varnish treatment, the scraps from a leather factory woven into a new, plush rug. Wood and metal hinges are polished and stressed before being transformed into a modern aesthetic mirror.
The posh reworkings are easily envisaged in one’s home interior and, the best part? Orders can be made to purchase each work (festive holiday decorations are also an option). Fusing the boundaries of exhibit, innovation and consumerism, Design Made works as a multi-dimensional goalpost for Choi, who seeks most of all to intergrate all the realms of design.
The director is also keeping busy with an ambitious outline of her wide-reaching plans: use existing conditions, artists and resources to build the KCDF; institute a global networking system (three months of steady calls have seen 23 universities worldwide come together for a future collaboration); and establish an online database for educational purposes.
“Crafts are filled with our long history, traditions and all these stories,” Choi said. “We’re fusing crafts and the modern together.”
More information on the KCDF and the Design Made exhibition can be found at www.kcdf.kr and www.designmade.org.

event_or_fact.property: Kaywon School of Art and Design
But because the history of industrial design isn?t that long, it has been Western culture ? and in particular Europe ? that has really influenced our mentality, led us and played a pivotal role,?
