description.hltext_display: Timeline: Asylum boat incidents
description.content: a wooden boat known as the SIEV-4, carrying 223 passengers and crew, sinks after being stopped by Australian officials attempting to turn it back to Indonesia. (AAP) The following is a chronology of events leading up to the crash of a boat carrying refugees that left 27 dead on Wednesday at Australia's Christmas Island.More than 100 boats carrying at least 5,000 refugees mostly from Iraq, Afghanistan and Sri Lanka, have arrived in Australia this year, the biggest surge in almost 10 years. Here are some key incidents involving refugee boats making for Australia in the past 10 years: August 2001: Australia denies permission for the Norwegian vessel the MV Tampa to enter its waters after rescuing 438 mainly Afghan refugees from a stranded boat off Christmas Island, sparking international condemnation. October 6, 2001: A wooden boat known as the SIEV-4, carrying 223 passengers and crew, sinks after being stopped by Australian officials attempting to turn it back to Indonesia. The incident came to be known as the "Children Overboard" affair after the government falsely claimed that the refugees were throwing infants into the water to try and force officials to bring them to Australia. October 19, 2001: An Indonesian fishing boat known as the SIEV-X sinks en route to Australia, carrying 421 passengers, mostly Iraqis and Afghans. Of those, 353 died, 146 of them children, in the most deadly incident involving refugees in Australia's history. April 16, 2009: Five Afghan refugees die when their boat explodes off Ashmore Reef, near Christmas Island, following an act of sabotage which also injured dozens of the 49 on board. October 10, 2009: A boat carrying more than 250 Sri Lankan Tamils bound for Australia is intercepted by Indonesian authorities on request from Canberra, prompting a six-month standoff at the port of Merak where they refused to disembark. October 18, 2009: Australia's Oceanic Viking Customs vessel rescues 78 Sri Lankan Tamils from their distressed ship in international waters, sparking a tense stand-off with Indonesia after the men refused to leave the ship at Tanjung Pinang. December 15, 2010: Twenty-seven refugees killed after a rickety boat shatters in cyclonic seas off Christmas Island, wounding more than 30.

description.hltext_display: Tourtiere for Christmas Eve
description.author: ELIZABETH BAIRD
description.content:
It?s all about anticipation ? even if you?re a grown-up, you feel the impending magic of Christmas Eve. With major cooking taking place the next day, Christmas Eve can be more relaxed, either by making the dishes ahead, or learning to follow the very easy rule of simple rather than complicated.
TOURTIERE
While not a drop of French blood flowed through my family?s veins, once we discovered tourtiere in the 1960s, we have never looked back to a pre-tourtiere Christmas Eve. This robust pie, anchored in Quebec culinary history, is enhanced by a tangy chili sauce or chutney, or even salsa.
1-1/2 cups (375 ml) cubed peeled potatoes
2 lb. (1 kg) ground lean pork
1 Tbsp. (15 ml) canola oil
3 onions, diced
3 cloves garlic, minced
2 cups (500 ml) sliced mushrooms
1 cup (250 ml) diced celery
1/2 tsp. (2 ml) each salt and freshly ground pepper 1/2 tsp. (2 ml) each dried crushed thyme and summer savory (or more thyme)
1/4 tsp. (1 ml) each ground cloves and cinnamon
1-1/2 cups (375 ml) chicken broth
1/4 cup (50 ml) minced parsley
Flaky Pastry for double crust 9- or 10-inch (23 or 25 cm) pie, see below
1 large egg
1 tsp. (5 ml) water
In a saucepan of boiling salted water, cook potatoes covered until fork tender, about 10 minutes. Drain and return to saucepan. Mash thoroughly; set aside.
Meanwhile in a Dutch oven (and without any fat), sear half of pork at a time, stirring and breaking up meat until no longer pink. Drain in large sieve set over bowl.
In same Dutch oven, and without cleaning it up, heat oil over medium heat; add onions, garlic, mushrooms, celery, salt, pepper, thyme, summer savory, cloves and cinnamon. Cook, stirring often, until vegetables are tender, about 10 minutes.
Pour in broth. Bring to a boil, reduce heat and simmer until a spoon drawn across bottom of Dutch oven leaves a space that fills in slowly. Remove from heat; add potatoes, stirring to mix thoroughly. Let cool for 30 minutes. Refrigerate, uncovered until cold. (Make-ahead: Store tourtiere filling in refrigerator for up to 1 day.)
Roll out slightly more than half of pastry on floured counter to 1/8-inch (3 mm) thickness. Fit into 9- or 10-inch (23 or 25 cm) pie plate without trimming overhang. Spoon filling evenly into pie shell.
For top, roll out remaining pastry to same thickness. Moisten pastry on rim of bottom pie shell with water. Cover with top pastry, pressing edges together to seal. With paring knife, trim off excess fat at edge of rim. Flute pastry on rim. (Make-ahead: Cover and refrigerate for up to 1 day, or wrap in heavy-duty foil and freeze for up to 1 month. Let thaw in refrigerator for 1-1/2 days).
Beat egg with water; brush this egg wash over surface of pie. Cut steam holes in centre of pie. If desired, roll out pastry scraps and cut out festive shapes. Arrange over pastry; brush over with egg wash. Bake in bottom third of preheated 375F. (190C.) oven until golden and steaming hot in the centre, about 40 to 45 minutes.
Makes 10 to 12 servings.
FLAKY PASTRY
3 cups (750 ml) all-purpose flour
1 tsp. (5 ml) salt
1/2 cup (125 ml) each cold butter and lard, cubed
1 large egg
2 tsp. (10 ml) white vinegar
Ice water
In a large bowl, whisk flour with salt. Using pastry blender, cut in butter until mixture forms coarse crumbs with a few large pea-sized pieces.
In measuring cup, whisk egg until smooth. Mix in vinegar and enough ice water to make 3/4 cup (175 ml). Drizzle over dry ingredients, tossing with fork until ragged dough forms.
Press into 2 discs. Wrap and refrigerate for 30 minutes or up to 3 days. (Make-ahead: Enclose in airtight container and freeze for up to 2 weeks.)
Makes enough pastry for 1 double-crust 9- or 10-inch (23 to 25 cm) pie.
FRITTO MISTO
In the Italian tradition, seafood is the Christmas Eve menu. At her home in Cambridge, Ontario, Giustina Fernandes chooses a pleasing combo of shrimp, squid (calimari) and white fish fillets, which she coats in a gossamer-thin batter and deep fries them all. Fresh lemons to squeeze over the portions are welcome.
1 cup (250 ml) all-purpose flour
2 tsp. (10 ml) baking powder
1/2 tsp. (2 ml) each salt and finely grated lemon rind
Generous pinch freshly ground pepper
2 lb. (1 kg) cod or halibut fillets
1 lb. (500 g) small squid (calamari), cleaned
1 lb. (500 g) large raw shrimp, peeled and deveined
Vegetable oil for deep frying
In a large bowl, whisk flour, baking powder, salt, lemon rind and pepper together. Whisk in 1 cup (250 ml) water, whisking until batter is smooth. Set aside.
Cut cod into 3-inch (8 cm) chunks. Cut any tentacles off shrimp and discard. Pat shrimp, cod and squid dry with towels.
In a deep fryer or heavy-bottomed saucepan, heat oil to 375F. (190C.) or until 1-inch (2.5 cm) cube of white bread turns golden in 30 seconds.
Using fork, dip shrimp, cod and squid, 1 piece at a time, into batter, letting excess drip back into bowl. Fry, in batches and turning halfway through, until golden, about 3 minutes. Using slotted spoon, transfer to paper towel-lined baking sheet. Keep warm in 250F. (120C.) oven for 30 minutes.
Makes 8 to 10 servings.
CHIPOTLE SWEET POTATO SOUP
Not at all traditional, but what a delicious way to enjoy a quiet Christmas Eve by the fire! Serve with Tortilla Crisps, below.
1/2 cup (125 ml) roasted peanuts, chopped
2 Tbsp. (30 ml) butter
2 onions, diced
3 cloves garlic, minced
1 Tbsp. (15 ml) grated gingerroot
2 tsp. (10 ml) minced chipotle pepper (1 medium)
2 Tbsp. (30 ml) tomato paste
5 cups (1.25 l) diced peeled sweet potatoes or butternut squash (3 medium potatoes or 1 butternut squash, 2-1/2 lb./1.75 kg)
1 baking potato, peeled and diced
6 cups (1.5 L) or 4 cups (1 L) chicken broth or vegetable broth
2/3 cup (150 ml) sour cream
1 ripe avocado, diced
In a Dutch oven over medium heat, toast peanuts until fragrant and slightly darkened, about 3 minutes. Remove half for garnish.
Add butter to peanuts in Dutch oven. When melted and foaming, stir in onions, garlic and ginger. Fry, stirring often, until onions are tender, about 5 minutes. Stir in chipotle pepper and tomato paste; fry, stirring, until darkened, about 2 minutes.
STOVE-TOP METHOD:
Stir in sweet and baking potatoes and broth. Bring to boil, reduce heat, cover and simmer until potatoes are fork tender, about 25 minutes.
Using an immersion blender, or stand blender in batches, puree until smooth.
Serve with dollop of sour cream, a few cubes of avocado and a nice sprinkle of reserved toasted peanuts.
Makes 6 servings.
SLOW COOKER METHOD:
Scrape into slow cooker. Stir in sweet and baking potatoes and 4 cups (1L) chicken broth. Cover and cook on low until vegetables are tender, about 4 hours.
Using an immersion blender, or stand blender in batches, puree until smooth.
Serve with dollop of sour cream, a few cubes of avocado and a nice sprinkle of reserved toasted peanuts.
Makes 6 servings.
TORTILLA CRISPS
Brush 6 small wheat or corn tortillas lightly with peanut oil; cut each into 8 wedges. Arrange on baking sheets; sprinkle with chili powder or sea salt if desired. Bake in centre of 350F (180C) until crisp and darkened slightly, about 8 minutes.

description.hltext_display: How To Clean Golf Clubs Correctly
description.content:
In golf, you may need to have various tools and accessories for you to play the game. These will make sure that you will be able to perform in the best that you can be. Some tools are really needed in golf like golf clubs, balls and golf bags. Other tools and accessories are optional. You may buy them or you may just settle with other things instead. One thing that you need to remember though is that you have to keep the quality of the tools and accessories used in golf. Keeping them in good state will ensure that they will last for a long period of time. The golf clubs that you have must be cleaned from time to time to ensure that rust and dirt will not just accumulate freely. There are some tips that you need to remember for you to be guided on the things that you need to do. Get a golf club cleaner.
GATHER THINGS
The first thing that you need to do is to gather all the things that you may need to clean the golf clubs that you have. You will need golf club cleaners to remove the dirt and rust easily. You can get them from stores. It is also important that you have steel wool and brushes that can effectively remove dirt from areas that are not that easy to access. Make sure that you also have dry and damp cloths with you. See golf club set now.
RUB
In order for you to remove the rust from the golf clubs, you need to rub it against a s steel wool. This rust develops overtime especially when the metal club is exposed to harmful environment for a long period of time. Get the rust off to make sure that your metal f golf club stays in good state.
REMOVE MARKS
For sure, there will be a lot of marks that you will see in the golf clubs. You have to remove them. Get the golf club cleaner and apply it to the golf club. Rub the cloth against the golf club and make sure that hand marks, golf marks and grass stains are easily removed.
CLEAN THE GROOVES
Some parts of the golf clubs are surely hard to reach. But you have to make sure that you also clean those parts. For you to do this, you may need to use a toothbrush. Use it to brush the grooves and remove the dirt. Apply soap or golf club cleaner to do it easily.
WASH AND DRY
After cleaning the different parts of the club, you need to wash and dry. Apply saddle soap and rub it against the club. Rinse it thereafter and make sure that the soap is removed. Dry it up using a dry cloth to ensure that rust will not just occur easily.
There are various things that you need to keep in your mind for you to be able to clean the golf clubs that you have at home. Keep the things in mind for you to be guided easily on the things that you may need to do.

description.hltext_display: Abbot calls for tougher boat policy
description.content: Abbot calls for policy change in wake of boat tragedy. (Getty) Federal Opposition Leader Tony Abbott is using the Christmas Island boat disaster to call for a return to Coalition asylum seeker policies.The government says about 48 people were killed when a boat carrying up to 100 people sank during rough conditions, just off the coast of the island . Mr Abbott is calling for a return to Howard government policies, including the re-introduction of offshore processing and temporary protection visas. He says asylum seekers should be discouraged from travelling to Australia by boat. "I do want to work constructively with the government but it has to be towards policies that work, ... policies that do stop the boats, the sorts of policies that we've been talking about for many months, " the opposition leader said. Nauru was used as an offshore centre to process asylum seekers under the Howard government, but was closed after Kevin Rudd became Prime Minister in 2007. Calls to reopen the centre have been rejected by Immigration Minister Chris Bowen, who says that would not prevent people smugglers from using unseaworthy ships. It would take considerable expense and effort to open the Nauru facility, Bowed said. "And of course, at Nauru, 95 per cent of the people processed at Nauru ended up in Australia or New Zealand". "So people smugglers and asylum seekers know that. They know that an offshore processing centre in the absence of a regional and international framework is no disincentive to come to Australia. So we have a different approach," he added. Prime Minister Julia Gillard has given no indication of any change in her asylum seeker policy. She says Australia is working with other nations throughout the region to try to stop people smugglers. "We have enjoyed some success in arresting people smugglers both in our region and in Australia itself. We will continue with those policies," the prime minister stressed. "We do though want to smash the people-smuggling business model. We do want to take out of the hands of people smugglers the very evil product that they sell and that is why we are working on a regional protection framework and regional processing centre." But the government has come under criticism from independent MP Andrew Wilkie who is instead calling for the intake of refugees to be doubled. Mr Wilkie has rejected the government's invitation to join a group of federal politicians looking at the Christmas Island boat disaster. He says both the Government and Opposition need to develop a fresh set of policies to deal with asylum-seekers. "Australia must take a more humanitarian and ethical approach to asylum seekers. These are after all among the most disadvantaged people on the planet," Mr Wilkie said. "We are a rich country and we can certainly accommodate many more asylum seekers in Australia. They shouldn't be demonised, they should be welcome." Meanwhile, police have interviewed three crew members from the boat which smashed into cliffs and broke apart last week. They say the survivors have said the engine was not sabotaged and preliminary assessments show the weather was a significant factor behind the tragedy. Australian Federal Police Superintendent Gavin Ryan says it is unclear whether the crew will be charged with manslaughter over the deaths. "The crew have been interviewed for offences. A brief of evidence has been compiled, Gavin Ryan said, adding, Based on what's happened in the past, I would well and truly anticipate that the crew would be charged in the future. But I don't want to go into specifics." A vigil was held on the island on Sunday for those who died in the disaster.

description.hltext_display: Amnesia, cancer, kidney failure couldn't keep Jo Kennedy down
description.author: THOMAS ST. MYER
description.content:
MUNCIE -- Jo Kennedy humbly describes herself as someone who's not very interesting. If she's not very interesting, then the rest of us are downright boring. The 69-year-old Muncie woman suffered amnesia that triggered complete memory loss, survived a rare type of cancer that led to kidney failure, lived on a dialysis machine and miraculously received a new kidney that saved her life when she was advised to prepare for the worst. Every time she has been dealt a potentially demoralizing blow, Kennedy has refused to buckle physically or mentally.
"Through it all, she's been a rock," says daughter Elizabeth Covington, who lives with Kennedy. "I haven't known a stronger woman than my mother."
Kennedy has drawn strength from the support of God, her three daughters, four siblings, six grandchildren and a best friend in 57-year-old Leila Parsons.
Parsons and Kennedy first befriended each other about 20 years ago as co-workers at Ball Memorial Hospital, where Kennedy baked and Parsons still cooks. Their relationship reached best-friend status four years later when Kennedy discovered she had cancer cells wrapped around her kidneys and pancreas.
"She came every day at the hospital and visited me and sat and talked to me," Kennedy says of Parsons. "She was my cheerleader, a great friend."
'It was horrible'
Just a year earlier, Parsons had been diagnosed with breast cancer and was in remission when Kennedy fell ill. Kennedy underwent CAT scans and X-rays that revealed nothing, but blood-test results followed by an exploratory surgery revealed the rare form of cancer.
Kennedy attacked the cancer aggressively through chemotherapy. She put her mind and body to the test with nine weekly sessions that lasted 24 hours each.
"It made me sleepy. It put sores in my mouth. It was horrible. It really was," she says. "The chemo burnt. It actually hurt. I had absolutely no appetite. Everything tastes very chemical, Everything you eat, it all tastes the same."
Kennedy withstood the discomfort to beat the cancer, but her kidneys took a beating in the process. She suffered through three kidney failures over the course of the nine-week treatment. Kennedy remembers one of those failures in particular. She came down with cold chills but her skin felt hot to the touch, so one of her daughters rushed her to the hospital where she spent yet another night hooked to machines with doctors and nurses monitoring her vital signs.

description.hltext_display: I have remained true to who we are: Jon Bon Jovi
description.content:
He is the New Jersey boy who went from blue-collar to global superstar and after three decades of rock and roll, Jon Bon Jovi is still on top of his game.
The frontman of the iconic band 'Bon Jovi', the highest grossing worldwide touring act of 2010, says that there is still a lot to learn, including the Sa Re Ga of Indian music. "I would like to visit India. Unfortunately, till now I haven't got any connections to the Indian music scene. I want to hear classical but never got a chance," Jovi said in a e-mail interview.
The singer-songwriter penned Bon Jovi's cult anthems like It's My Life and Living On a Prayer and their Greatest Hits album recently peaked at the top spot in global charts.
The secret to it all is rather simple, says the rocker who at 50, still has the full head of blonde hair that made him a global sex symbol. "We have remained true to who we are and I love my work. That, according to me is a blessing. No matter who you are or what you do, if you love your work, you are blessed," said Jovi. 'Bon Jovi' consisting of lead singer and namesake Jon Bon Jovi, guitarist Richie Sambora, keyboardist David Bryan, drummer Tico Torres and bassist Hugh McDonald, broke on to the scene with the hit Runaway in 1983.
But the rocker says that the he and his bandmates have long outgrown the spandex-wearing dudes they were when they began with Runaway. And that reflects in their music. "Throughout the years our music has grown and matured and become a little more social conscious but like I said we are true to who we are," said Jovi whose charity the Jon Bon Jovi Soul Foundation helps build homes for the poor in his native New Jersey.
The band recently won the Global Icon trophy at the MTV awards and Jovi had recently announced that he may be hanging up the boots to become a family man for his four children and wife, high school sweetheart, Dorothea Hurley.
But Jovi says that he measures success by not how long they will stay but with how long they have come. "We, as a band have come a long way. With every new day, we have learnt something new. For us, the success of our career over the years is how we like to measure our success," said Jovi. His much awaited Mumbai performance at Live Earth was cut short by the Mumbai terror attacks in 2008. And Jovi says that he will make up when he finally visits. "I will make an announcement when I am visiting," promises the rocker.

description.hltext_display: Fate of shipwreck orphan hangs in balance
description.content: Relatives of the boy are being sought. (AAP) There are no plans to provide a boy orphaned in the Christmas Island boat tragedy with an advocate, reports the ABC.Immigration officials are trying to track down the relatives of the child orphaned in last week's fatal accident. About 48 Iranian, Iraqi and Kurdish asylum seekers died when their boat smashed apart on rocks in high seas last Wednesday. However, only 30 bodies have been recovered so far. Forty-two people survived, including three children who are now orphans. A spokeswoman for the Department of Immigration and Citizenship on Tuesday said that two of the children are cousins and had been reunited with a family member who also survived the accident, AAP reported. "We are currently trying to explore as many avenues as we can to identify any family members of that particular child who may be in Australia," the spokeswoman told AAP. On Wednesday, Peter Richards from the Department of Immigration said it was too early to speculate whether Immigration Minister Chris Bowen was an appropriate guardian for the boy - as is the case under Australian law. "I think it's very premature to be speculating around what the best answer may be in relation to that child," the ABC reported Mr Richards as saying. "That is something that we will consider over the coming days and weeks." Immigration officials are interviewing survivors and sifting through calls logged on the emergency helpline set up following the incident to try to find more information about the child. People who think they may know someone involved in the disaster can call 1300 724 010 in Australia or +61 39 936 5436 from overseas, 24 hours a day.

description.hltext_display: Mobilfunker erhalten mehr Macht
Ducks get hit early in loss
description.author: The Associated
description.content:
BUFFALO, N.Y. - The Buffalo Sabres got an early jump Tuesday on the Ducks, and Ducks coach Randy Carlyle said it was obvious why.
"They definitely had a lot more energy than we did," he said after a 5-2 loss that included a first-period, 3-0 deficit. "We didn't show that we had much energy or sharpness."
Corey Perry scored two goals and backup Curtis McElhinney made 37 saves for the Ducks, who won 3-0 at Boston on Monday and lost for the first time in five meetings with the Sabres.
Anaheim went 2-3 on its seven-day road trip and will be off until after the Christmas break.
"You never think that after a first period you'd be down 3-0. It's tough to bear," Ducks forward Bobby Ryan said. "You never expect it."
After the opening-period blitz by the Sabres, there were three fights in the second period. Ducks captain Ryan Getzlaf and Sabres center Cody McCormick fought immediately after the opening faceoff in the second. Five seconds later, the Ducks' Kyle Chipchura and Buffalo's Paul Gaustad dropped gloves.
"It's all part of the motivation thing," Getzlaf said of the fights that failed to ignite the Ducks. "It was a fact that I wanted to get my team going.
"I didn't feel we were ready to play the hockey game in the first period."
Curtis McElhinney made his eighth start of the season in place of No. 1 goalie Jonas Hiller, who has played an NHL-high 32 games.
Sabres captain Craig Rivet, playing for the first
time in nearly a month, had a goal and assist and Tyler Ennis scored two goals for the Sabres.
Buffalo's embattled leader had been a healthy scratch for the past 11 games - and 16 times this season - but he was added to the lineup because of defenseman Chris Butler's recent struggles.
Rivet responded by scoring his first goal of the season and earning a team-high, plus-2 rating.
"There's been a lot of mixed emotions that I've had over the last month or so," he said. "But those are things I'm going to work through. That's the type of person that I am.
"I was battling some tough situations. I'm happy that I was able to come out and help our team a little bit. If I can continue that, it's all I can ask for."
Ennis wasn't surprised with how Rivet came back, and told the 16-year NHL veteran before the game he had a feeling Rivet would get that elusive goal.
"He played awesome," Ennis said. "The last month he's been really supportive in the room, and has been a great leader. It was great to see him play well."
Sabres coach Lindy Ruff, though, seemed cautiously encouraged with Rivet's performance.
"I thought he was better," Ruff said. "I thought there was some defensive zone stuff I'd like to clean up."
Ryan Miller, making his 11 th consecutive start, earned his 199 th NHL win. His shutout bid was spoiled when Perry scored a power-play goal with 4:24 to go. Miller finished with 21 saves.
Drew Stafford and Nathan Gerbe also scored and Derek Roy and Jordan Leopold each added a pair of assists for the Sabres, who rebounded from losses to Florida and Tampa Bay over the weekend.
The Sabres stretched their lead to 4-0 on Ennis' second goal of the game and ninth of the season at 4:40 of the second. The rookie wristed a shot into the top corner from the faceoff circle.
Stafford made it 1-0 with his ninth of the season on the power play 4:43 into the game, and Gerbe doubled the lead with his first this season, putting in a rebound from the slot.
Ducks forward Jason Blake then was given a major penalty and was ejected after he drove Sabres forward Patrick Kaleta into the boards from behind with 6:24 left in the first. Ennis capitalized on the long power play with 3:03 to go to make it 3-0.
Rivet made it 5-1 with his first with 2:57 left in the game. Perry capped the scoring with a power-play goal with nine seconds remaining.
Also ...
The Ducks recalled left wing Josh Green from Syracuse of the AHL after center Nick Bonino injured a foot against Boston. He is day-to-day. ... Sabres center Tim Connolly missed the game because of a fractured nose sustained against Tampa Bay on Saturday. He will be out at least a week. ... Miller got engaged over the weekend to Noureen DeWulf.

description.hltext_display: Hanson-Young wants children's commissioner
description.content:
Two aunties of a child orphaned when the boat he was on was wrecked on Christmas Island have also now arrived on boats.The boy is one of three children left orphaned after a wooden asylum-seeker boat was smashed to pieces on rocks at Christmas Island last Wednesday.
An immigration spokesman said the boy would be reunited with his aunts who had since arrived on Christmas Island on other boats.
Psychologists are guiding the department on the reunion, the spokesman said.
The boy reportedly is from Iran but the department says it cannot confirm the boy's nationality.
He was one of 42 survivors rescued after the boat disintegrated when it was washed against the island's rugged shores in rough seas. It is thought 48 people perished.
Authorities believe as many as 90 people were on the boat but Prime Minister Julia Gillard has said it may never be known exactly how many people were on the boat and some of the bodies may never be recovered.

description.hltext_display: Fix something fishy for Christmas Eve
description.content:
Many have established a tradition of having Christmas dinner on Christmas Eve. That way, they reason, they can have a far more relaxed Christmas Day, enjoying the family and friends and gifts without having to cut the togetherness short to make Christmas dinner.
It's really a terrific idea. But we never got into that tradition. Mainly because the Christmas Eve menu we grew up with was all Italian, while we reserved the Dec. 25 dinner menu for more traditional American fare: turkey or roast beast, plus the trimmings.
Our activity du jour, then, is all about a menu that you may want to try on Christmas Eve or sometime during the season. Of course, you, and we, can eat Italian any day. Indeed, you probably have some nifty Italian dishes in your repertoire. But that long-ago Christmas Eve menu was different, because of the Roman Catholic tradition of fasting from meat on Christmas Eve day and sticking to seafood.
Tradition also had it that a fitting menu for that holy night should consist of at least seven types of seafood. Some families even argued that there should be 12 types of seafood, to honor the 12 Apostles.
My old grandmother and aunties and cousins stuck with the seven seafoods, though. Among them was a salad of black olives and shredded salt cod (soaked for three days) tossed with oil and vinegar. And fried eel (which swam in the bathtub for a couple of days before the "hit.") And fried fresh cod. And aglio e olio, featuring linguine doused with a sauce of garlic, anchovies and chopped hazelnuts cooked in olive oil.
When I had my feet under my own table, I more or less re-established that tradition, while putting my own stamp on the meal. I don't do the salt cod salad. I don't do eel. But I definitely do aglio e olio, using pecans instead of hazelnuts.
For the rest, there are "regular" recipes, plus annual experiments. Among them are these, which you will probably enjoy fixing, and which your family and guests will definitely enjoy eating. Except for the allergics, of course.
Our menu features dishes that are designed to provide eight servings each, but with some creative plating, there's usually enough to make 10 to 12 of your nearest and dearest very happy. Think small plates.
Buon natale!
Artichoke and crab dip
When feeding family and friends some more "exotic" dishes, it's always good to lull them with something familiar. Hence this appetizer dip, which we've made more eater-friendly by using light mayonnaise and sour cream, and less of it than many such recipes call for.
Of course, you'll want to have plenty of lightly toasted baguette slices for dunking/spreading.
A white wine's fine with this offering. Or open up the evening with some sparkling prosecco (Italian bubbly).
You can prep the dip a day ahead, cover and refrigerate until time to bake. Toast the baguette slices ahead, too. Cool and place in airtight bags. Heat gently, if you wish.
8 tablespoons (packed) grated romano cheese
6 tablespoons light mayonnaise 6 tablespoons light sour cream
3/4 teaspoon marjoram
1/2 teaspoon each, onion powder and garlic powder
1/4 teaspoon coarsely ground black pepper
Pinch of cayenne pepper
2 packages frozen artichoke hearts, thawed, patted dry, chopped into one-fourth inch pieces
1/2 pound (or a bit more) blue crab meat (claw meat is fine)
3 tablespoons shredded parmesan cheese
About 1/2 teaspoon paprika
In a medium bowl, whisk together romano cheese, mayonnaise, sour cream, marjoram, onion and garlic powders, black pepper and cayenne. Stir in artichokes and crab. Remove to a 3 cup baking dish/ramekin. If not cooking right away, cover and refrigerate until about 1 hour before serving.
To bake, heat oven to 375 degrees. Bake artichoke/crab mixture for 20 to 30 minutes, until heated through. Remove from oven to a rack.
To finish, preheat broiler. Sprinkle dip with the shredded parmesan and then paprika. Broil until cheese is melty, about 3 minutes. Serve warm with toasted baguettes. Makes about 3 cups dip.
Haddock and clams
If you can't find haddock for this first course, try cod. And look for the tiniest littleneck clams you can get.
3 pounds haddock fillets (about 1 1/4 inch thick), cut into 8 or more equal pieces
Freshly ground pepper
1/4 cup flour
1/4 cup olive oil, divided
4 garlic cloves, minced
2 pounds littleneck clams, scrubbed
3/4 cup dry white wine
3/4 cup bottled clam broth
1/4 cup (4 tablespoons) unsalted butter
1/4 cup chopped flat-leaf parsley
About 1/8 teaspoon smoked (sweet) paprika, optional
For the fish, heat oven to 375 degrees. Season fish with pepper, then dust lightly with flour.
In a large, ovenproof skillet, over medium-high, heat 2 tablespoons of the olive oil until just shimmering. Add fish, 4 pieces at a time, and cook until golden on the bottom, about 4 minutes. Turn fish over. Remove to a plate and keep warm with foil. Repeat with remaining fish fillets.
Return the first fish pieces you cooked to the skillet. Place skillet in oven and roast for about 10 minutes, until fish flakes with a fork. Transfer to shallow soup plates.
While fish roasts, in a large skillet, heat remaining olive oil until shimmering. Add garlic and clams and cook over high heat for 2 minutes. Add wine and cook, stirring, for 2 minutes. Add clam broth and cook, stirring for 2 more minutes. Reduce heat, cover and steam just until clams open, about 4 minutes. Remove cover. Turn off heat.
To serve, use a slotted spoon to divide clams among the 8 soup plates with the fish. Stir butter into broth in skillet, until melted. Stir in parsley and paprika. Spoon broth equally among soup plates. Serve with chewy Italian bread. Makes 8 or more servings.
Spaghetti alla pescatore
Sounds better in Italian, but it's basically pasta with seafood. Here, we use four of them: clams (again), mussels, shrimp and rockfish. You can also add about 1/2 pound cleaned, cooked squid rings along with the shrimp, mussels, etc. (See below.)
The shrimp should be cooked ahead. You can buy cooked shrimp, or steam it yourself, a la Maryland: over wine in this case, with a bit of Old Bay. Cool, peel, devein before adding to the other goodies in this sauce. You might want to steam a mess of shrimp and save some of it to use for a shrimp cocktail appetizer on Christmas Day.
In American tradition, we usually offer a simple salad (lettuce, arugula, radicchio and toasted almonds with vinegar and oil) with the pasta, but in Europe this would be served after the main course, as a palate cleanser before dessert. We leave that to you.
2 pounds littleneck clams, scrubbed
2 pounds mussels, scrubbed, debearded
1 small onion, in chunks
Pinch of hot red pepper flakes
1 1/4 cups water
1/3 cup olive oil
2 small, dried hot red peppers, caps and seeds removed
3 cloves garlic, chopped
1 pound cooked (peeled, deveined) shrimp
3/4 pound rockfish (or haddock) fillets, in 1-inch pieces
1/3 cup finely chopped flat-leaf parsley, divided
1 1/4 cup dry white wine
Scant 2 pounds spaghetti (Number 8)
1 teaspoon sea salt
3 tablespoons each, minced fresh thyme and oregano
Plenty of shredded parmesan cheese, for serving
For clams and mussels, in a large, deep skillet, combine clams and mussels with the onion chunks, hot red pepper flakes and the 1 1/4 cups water, cover and bring to a boil. Boil until clams and mussels open, about 8 minutes. Remove shellfish with a slotted spoon to a bowl to cool enough to handle. Remove clams and mussels from shells and set aside. Strain cooking liquid and reserve 1/3 cup of it.
In a large, non-stick skillet, over medium, heat olive oil. Add hot peppers and garlic and saute until garlic is soft but not browned. Add shrimp and rockfish and about 2 tablespoons of the parsley. Stir for 2 minutes. Add clams and mussels, reserved shellfish cooking liquid, wine and salt. Cover and simmer until rockfish is done and other seafood is heated through, about 5 minutes.
Meanwhile, in a large pot, bring 6 quarts of lightly salted water to a boil. Add spaghetti and cook until al dente, according to package directions. Drain well and arrange on a large serving platter.
To serve, pour seafood mixture over spaghetti. Sprinkle with thyme, rosemary and remaining parsley and mix well. Serve immediately. Pass the parmesan. Makes 8 or more servings.

description.hltext_display: European airports fight to clear backlog
description.content:
European airports fought to clear a backlog of thousands of stranded Christmas travellers on Wednesday as arctic conditions gripped the continent and sparked fresh delays and cancellations.Weary passengers faced another day stuck in terminals amid fresh snowfalls and continued freezing temperatures which have hit airports in Britain, Germany, France and Ireland.
Britain has offered to send in troops to end the disruption at London Heathrow, while Frankfurt and Dublin airports faced severe disruption.
Eurocontrol, the continent's air traffic supervisory body, said about 3000 flights had been cancelled across Europe on Tuesday, with similar numbers of cancellations for each of the past four days.
The cold snap chaos also hit Europe's rail network with long queues snaking outside the London terminal for the Eurostar train link between Britain, France and Belgium.
There was a glimmer of hope for angry passengers who have spent four nights sleeping under foil blankets at Heathrow, Europe's busiest airport, as its second runway reopened late Tuesday.
But the huge backlog at one of the busiest times of year meant services will not immediately return to normal, and the airport planned to run about two-thirds of flights on Wednesday.
"It is good news to see aircraft taking off and landing from two runways," Colin Matthews, chief executive of airport operator BAA told Sky News.
"But it's really important that passengers understand that doesn't mean the full schedule is going to be restored instantly."
Airport officials were under increasing pressure to resolve the crisis on Wednesday after the EU lashed out at the "unacceptable" disruption caused by the heavy snows.
"I am extremely concerned about the level of disruption to travel across Europe caused by severe snow. It is unacceptable and should not happen again," European transport commissioner Siim Kallas said.
British Prime Minister David Cameron said he had offered to use the military to help BAA resolve the crisis at Heathrow, but this offer was refused.
"The people stuck there are having an incredibly difficult time, especially just a few days from Christmas, and everything must be done to either get them on holiday or get them home safely," Cameron told a press conference.
Anger was meanwhile mounting among passengers queuing in the cold outside the terminal buildings at Heathrow.
"I think this hurts the reputation of the whole country. The airport is the first experience you have and this is not a good experience," Gustaf Malmstrom, 23, told Agence France-Presse as he tried for a fifth day to get a flight to Stockholm.
Most of Heathrow's five terminals were only letting in people who were flying on Tuesday morning, mainly on flights to Asia, while others had to queue outside. Workers handed out silver foil blankets and set up two heated tents.
Eurostar said it was running a restricted service and asked all customers booked to travel before Christmas to refund or exchange their tickets free of charge if their journey was not essential.
The queue of passengers stretched for more than a kilometre around the imposing St Pancras station, and Eurostar warned the chaos looked set to continue.
"It's too early at the moment to say when we will get back to normal," a spokeswoman told AFP.
In Germany fresh snowfall caused gridlock at the country's main airport Frankfurt with no flights taking off or landing for about three-and-a-half hours in the morning.
Many internal flights were cancelled because of the arctic conditions, prompting German train company Deutsche Bahn to announce additional services on major routes across the country to help stranded travellers.
Dublin airport grounded all flights until 0800 GMT on Wednesday (1900 AEDT) after Ireland was hit by more than 15 centimetres of snow.
In France authorities allowed the two main airports in Paris, Charles de Gaulle and Orly, to remain open around the clock to clear the backlog of delayed flights.

description.hltext_display: Taylor hints at Newcastle stay
description.content:
Manager Alan Pardew appears to have succeeded in convincing Steven Taylor that he should stay at Newcastle.
The centre-back will be out of contract in the summer and he has been linked with Premier League rivals Arsenal.
But since Pardew arrived at St James' Park earlier in December he has made it his priority to hold talks with the 24-year-old.
The pair have been in discussion and Taylor admits he is impressed with his new boss, suggesting that a contract extension may not be too far away.
"It's been a difficult year for me with injuries, but it looks as if it could be finishing on a high," said Taylor in the Daily Star.
He added: "I have been very impressed with the new manager. Since he came in, he has been absolutely spot-on.
"Within a day or two, he sat me down in his office and made it clear he wants me to be here. It was music to my ears.
"Everyone knows how much I want to stay here, so for him to say he will do everything he can for me was brilliant."

event_or_fact.property: I have been very impressed with the new manager.
he is impressed with his new boss, suggesting that a contract extension may not be too far away
It's been a difficult year for me with injuries, but it looks as if it could be finishing on a high

description.hltext_display: SKorean soldiers guard Christmas tree
description.content:
The 155-metre hill, about three kilometres from the border, is within range of North Korean gunfire. (AAP) South Korean marines were on guard on Tuesday to protect a Christmas tree, the latest focus of tensions with North Korea following Seoul's artillery drill near the disputed sea border a day earlier.A South Korean church planned to switch on Christmas lights in the shape of a tree atop a military-controlled hill near the tense land border later in the day - the first such display for seven years.
The ceremony will come a day after South Korea staged a live-fire exercise on the border island of Yeonpyeong, which was bombarded by North Korea last month.
The North forswore retaliation despite previously vowing a deadly response to the South's drill. But officials were concerned the Christmas tree could become a target for attack. "Marines are maintaining the highest level of alertness around the hill," a defence ministry spokesman told AFP, citing the North's continued threats to strike border propaganda facilities.
The 155-metre hill, about three kilometres from the border, is within range of North Korean gunfire.
The two Koreas in 2004 reached a deal to halt official-level cross-border propaganda and the South stopped its annual Christmas tree illumination ceremony.
The communist North had accused the South of displaying Christmas lights to spread religion among its people and soldiers. The North's constitution provides for religious freedom, but the US State Department says this does not in practice exist.
The South has partially resumed a cross-border government propaganda campaign following the sinking in March of a South Korean warship and the bombardment of Yeonpyeong, which killed four people including civilians.
Soon after last month's artillery attack, the South's military reportedly floated 400,000 leaflets across the border denouncing the North's regime.
The South has also installed loudspeakers along the land border but has not yet switched them on. They are designed to blast anti-regime and pro-democracy messages deep into the border region.
North Korea has threatened to open fire on the speakers if they are switched on, and also to fire at locations from where leaflets are released.
Private activist groups frequently float huge balloons across the heavily fortified frontier. These carry tens of thousands of leaflets denouncing the regime of Kim Jong-Il.

description.hltext_display: Code enforcement closes 30-year case
description.author: Kyle Magin Staff Writer
description.content: Nevada County officials have put an end to a $30,000, 31-year nuisance case in Penn Valley. County Code Enforcement personnel removed used car parts, tires, wood scraps and other solid waste from a property on the 17000 block of Indian Springs Road last week, closing a case open since 1979. The owner of the property, Carl Feisel, was unavailable for comment Monday. Feisel will be billed by the county's code enforcement team for staff time over the three weeks between Nov. 20 and Dec. 13 spent cleaning the property, plus court costs associated with the abatement, said Code Compliance Program Manager Gregory Shaffer. "Without the (sheriff's) officers time, I'm estimating the cost is about $30,000," Shaffer added. The current case began when the Nevada County Sheriff's Office lodged a complaint in 2006, Shaffer said. To contact Staff Writer Kyle Magin, e-mail kmagin@theunion.com or call (530) 477-4239. Copyright 2010 The Union. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed. The Union December, 21 2010 8:54 pm MST

description.hltext_display: WATER: Early Rains Rekindle Interest in Rainwater Harvesting
description.author: Ignatius Banda
description.content: (IPS) - In Thembekie Gwebus yard under the roof leaves stands a curious giant green plastic container with a plastic pipe connected to the gutter. She has been asked a number of times by curious visitors and passers-by what the contraption is, and she happily explains. Gwebu, a 60-something year-old widow, uses the container for rainwater harvesting. At a time when the Bulawayo municipality has introduced water-shedding as part of long existing efforts to conserve the disappearing water from supply dams, the coming of the rain in this city traditionally characterised by low rainfall - has been welcomed by residents like Gwebu as an opportunity to use rainwater collected from roofs for their daily needs. "This helps during the time when there is water rationing," Gwebu says. Even when there is water running from the taps, the harvested rainwater has come handy in reducing the council water she would otherwise pay for. Gwebu is one of a growing number of residents in this city of more than two million who have rediscovered the old method of water conservation through harvesting rainwater for domestic use, when in the past many had relegated this to rural communities. However, the continued water woes in this City have awakened many here to how this naturally available resource can be harnessed and exploited. "I use the rainwater I harvest for drinking, cooking, laundry and also in the toilet," Gwebu said, adding that the water stored in the 2,500 litre bowser can last her up to a month. Not only does this conserve the municipal water from supply dams but she also does not pay her water bill for the month. Rainwater harvesting is increasingly being encouraged across the Southern Africa Development Community, SADC, as an alternative provision of clean drinking water at a time when some communities are failing to adequately exploit groundwater amid concerns of contamination and pollution. These household rainfall catchment systems have also been commended by the SADCs Water Division, as the rainwater harvested from roofs does not require treatment before consumption and they are also a means to mitigate the effects of long dry spells in cities like Bulawayo. "I was in Maun, Botswana recently and I was impressed at the extent to which rainwater is being used," said Barbra Lopi, Communications and Events Officer with the SADC Groundwater and Drought Management Project. "Nearly every household, and almost all schools, have a rainwater collection facility and the water collected is used for gardening and in the toilets and for laundry" she said. The SADC Groundwater and Drought Management Project says up to 70 percent of people in the region rely on groundwater, but the shift to rainwater harvesting will ensure better sustainability as this resource is not depleted by falling water tables. The interest in rainwater harvesting is also critical in ensuring that countries that have struggled to provide adequate access to clean water meet their Millennium Development Goal number 7 - that seeks to provide safe drinking water and sanitation by 2015. The NGO, Plan Action, says rainwater harvesting in Zimbabwes low rainfall southern regions under which Bulawayo has assisted to improvelivelihoods with improved harvests, has meant that households have been able to reverse the threat of food insecurity. "Even for areas like urban Bulawayo, rainwater harvesting has been successful in ensuring that households can store much-needed extra water even when the rains are low," said Gilbert Nyoni a, field officer with Plan Action. "People need containers that can adequately store the water for extended use," Sibanda said. While a few residents like Gwebu have benefitted from huge bowsers donated by World Vision in conjunction with the Swedish International Development Agency,SIDA, others like Sithembeni Dube use makeshift containers to harvest the rainwater. "I use these dishes and jerry cans and its painful for me when there is so much rain and I fail to trap the water," Dube said, expressing a common sentiment among residents here who have rediscovered the benefits of rainwater harvesting. In the 1990's, the Zimbabwe Council of Churches set up the Rainwater Harvesting Programme in Bulawayo after a realisation that even if more boreholes were sunk in this dry city, they would only be a drain on the water table and would also require constant maintenance. And today, with the growing awareness among households, this could be what the doctor ordered as the rains continue to pound the city albeit intermittently. "This has been particularly helpful to vulnerable groups like the elderly, who lack resources to pay for council water," said Pastor James Choruma, who works with the implementation of community-based sustainable development initiatives in Bulawayo. "I think what is important is that this interest in water harvesting will benefit residents who have learnt to live with water cuts and burst sewers, so if they are able to store as much water as they can, it means they have water to flush their toilets," Choruma said. The Department of Geography and Environmental Science at the University of Zimbabwe says it is fairly easy for residents to adopt rainwater harvesting technologies as they are cheap, and this can go a long way toward improving environmental management among poor communities. This, the department says, can also assist in the resuscitation of wetlands. For Gwebu meanwhile, harvesting rainwater is a boon that she hopes will give her enough water to drink when other residents make a beeline to congested municipality boreholes scattered across Bulawayo when taps run dry.

I think what is important is that this interest in water harvesting will benefit residents who have learnt to live with water cuts and burst sewers, so if they are able to store as much water as they can, it means they have water to flush their toilets

description.hltext_display: NBN hook-up to take nearly a decade
description.content:
A basic feed from the National Broadband Network will cost telecommunications wholesalers $24 a month, the federal government has revealed, and will take nine years to connect more than 10 million homes.Communications Minister Stephen Conroy released the long-awaited NBN business plan in Canberra on Monday. The basic plan will offer download speeds of 12 megabits per second and upload speeds of one megabit per second. "NBN Co's expected internal rate of return is 7.0 per cent," documents provided to reporters by the company show. 70 per cent uptake expected
The assumption is based on a 70 per cent takeup of the network by businesses and homes. Further to the expected rate of return is the prediction of a $13.4 billion capital raising from the markets by 2015. The NBN will deliver fibre to the home for 93 per cent of the nation with the remaining seven per cent of premises to be covered by either wireless or satellite. Specific targets for the rollout of the yet-to-be-built network were also included in the business plan which was released alongside the corporate watchdog's advice to government. All of these predictions and plans remain dependent on what NBN chief Mike Quigley described as the "consummation" of the deal between NBN Co and Telstra. Mr Quigley told reporters discussions with the nation's largest telecommunications provider would continue throughout the Christmas break. "I spoke with (Telstra boss) David Thodey this morning," Mr Quigley said. The initial $24 price for a basic NBN service will drop overtime, the plan promises. Mr Quigley described as "conservative" the assumptions on future growth made in the business plan. "The growth in demand for speeds will be considerably lower than the extrapolation of increasing speeds implied by the history of internet access technologies," the plan said. Prime Minister Julia Gillard, Communications Minister Stephen Conroy, Treasurer Wayne Swan and Finance Minister Penny Wong were addressing reporters on the business plan. The plan had been under wraps since early November, despite repeated calls to release it. The government last month made a 36-page summary available to appease its critics. The full 400-page document has now been released.
Gillard defends viability
Prime Minister Julia Gillard says the business plan proves that the network will be both viable and affordable, as it will be delivered at a smaller cost than originally thought. It will also be profitable, meaning taxpayers' investment in the NBN "will be returned with interest", while uniform wholesale prices will also be achieved, she said. "Those prices will be affordable for consumers," she told reporters in Canberra. Ms Gillard said the plan proved the NBN would deliver major benefits for Australia, lauding it as the "telecommunications development of our century".

description.hltext_display: Present peeking mostly leads to regret
description.content:
One in five British adults have torn the wrapping paper enough to be able to identify a gift. (Getty) About one in three British adults already know what they will receive for Christmas - because they have snuck a peek at their presents, a new study showed this week.The survey of 1,000 people by British insurance company insurastore.com showed that 37 percent of British adults admitted to searching for their presents, and out of those, eight in 10 were successful in the hunt. "Kids aside, it seems even adults have a fascination for what Father Christmas might have bought them and keeping surprises under wraps is a considerable challenge in any household," insurastore Managing Director Paul Maddicott said. One in five British adults have torn the wrapping paper enough to be able to identify a gift and one in 20 admitted to unwrapping presents completely, the survey revealed.
The average snooper spends an hour and 15 minutes seeking out Christmas gifts. Respondents ranked the top of the wardrobe and under the bed as the most common hiding places.
However, more than half of those who discovered what they were getting for Christmas (56 percent) later regretted their curiosity and said they wished they had not looked. Four in 10 even complained that they had spoiled Christmas. "We'd definitely urge anyone who's curious to try and resist temptation as the spoilt surprise and feelings of guilt are likely to take the fun out of Xmas day," Mr Maddicott said. The study also found that women were more inquisitive than men, with 40 percent of women admitting to hunting for presents compared to 33 percent of men. But women were also more likely to own up with one in 20 admitting to their boyfriend or husband that they had sneaked a peek at their presents.
(Editing by Paul Casciato)

event_or_fact.property: Kids aside, it seems even adults have a fascination for what Father Christmas might have bought them and keeping surprises under wraps is a considerable challenge in any household
We'd definitely urge anyone who's curious to try and resist temptation as the spoilt surprise and feelings of guilt are likely to take the fun out of Xmas day

description.hltext_display: Xbox 360 shopping guide
description.author: Chris Vandergaag
description.content:
Xbox 360 was re-designed this year by Microsofta slimmer cabinet outside and a handful of improvements inside make the new S (for slim) version of the gaming console a nicer piece of gear than ever. As always, though, buying a new 360 as a holiday gift for your family isnt as simple as just plucking one from a shelf and booking it for the check-out before the crowds consume youits offered in a variety of configurations and at various price points. Dont rely on frazzled, overworked store clerks to assess your needs and adequately guide youenter the store equipped with knowledge! This primer will get you started:
Xbox 360 250GB - $299.99
Your basic Xbox 360 configuration, which includes console, a now-standard 250GB hard drive (last years base model shipped with 120GB), power cables and one controller. All you need to get started.
However, the wireless controller included with the 360 doesnt come with a rechargeable battery pack a $29 Charge And Play Kit is highly recommended. When buying additional controllers, look for ones labeled Xbox 360 Accessory Pack Wireless Controller ($69.99) as these include a Charge And Play Kit for only $10 more than controllers sans charge kit.
Xbox 360 250GB Holiday Bundle 2010 - $299.99
With two terrific games, Forza Motorsport 3 and Alan Wake (no tossed-in remainder stock here, but rather, two of the best titles available for 360, included at no additional cost), the limited-time holiday bundle is possibly the best way to bring an Xbox 360 home, at least for anyone not convinced they need a Kinect.
Xbox 360 250GB Kinect bundle - $399.99
A 250GB 360 bundled with a Kinect package, which includes sensor, cables and the game Kinect Adventures. This bundle represents a $50 savings, as Kinect packages cost $149.99 when purchased separately.
Xbox 360 4GB - $199.99
Priced for shelf appeal at $199, this configuration costs $100 less than the standard 360 bundle, and includes no hard drive, but 4GB of on-board memorynot enough room to install discs or download many Xbox Live Arcade games, but enough for system resources, your save data, and your personal info. I cant recommend going this route, though. Invariably, Xbox 360 4GB owners (like last generations Xbox 360 Arcade model owners) quickly find their options limited and their enjoyment hampered by the lack of a hard drive, and the cost of adding one after-the-fact ($129.99) is greater than the difference between budget-priced 4GB and properly equipped 250GB models.
Features of the new S model 360 New 360 Slims are smaller, and run quieter and cooler than previous generation models, but my favorite new feature (I just upgraded) is the Slims on-board optical audio output for surround sound (in order to deliver true Dolby 5.1, previous Xboxes required either an optical audio adapter, sold separately, or owning a fairly recent generation stereo receiver, capable of carrying both video and surround sound over HDMI). The inclusion of a 250GB hard driveeven while trying to be space-conscious, I filled up the 120GB drive in my old console quicklyis also a big plus. Additionally, new 360s can power and communicate with Kinect with a single wire (old models require a separate power supply for Kinect, and occupy a USB port, leaving you with only 2) uses touch-pad buttons, and has more USB ports overall5 free ports, even with Kinect plugged in.
Red Ring Redemption
Best of all, the Xbox 360 S is now reportedly immune to the infamous "red ring of death", a term used to describe an all-too-common failure of core Xbox components, related to improper dissipation of heatXbox 360s notoriously ran too hotand characterized by front panel LEDs lighting up in a red circle; hence the red ring. Though Microsoft was accommodating, with regards to extending warranty coverage to protect against red-ringing consoles, the failure rate of previous generation 360s remained cause for concern. While failures were much less common in later builds of the old model (including my Elite 120GB with the 'Jasper' chipset), I'm still reassured by the fact the 360 is now a more reliable machine. IMPORTANT A word about cables
Xbox 360s require HDMI or component cables (HDMI being the new standard, and required for true 1080p) to operate in high definition, and sadly, neither cable is included in any of the bundles. Pick one up when you get your 360, but dont allow yourself to be talked into buying Monster brand; theyre still notoriously overpriced. In fact, most HDTV cables offered by Best Buy, Future Shop, and other major retailers cost too much. Go online. NCIX.com is a Canadian retailer with a great reputation, which sells a variety of cables at good prices.

description.hltext_display: Aussie women choose tradies over princes
description.content: A survey by the Australian Women's Weekly shows that most Aussie women would choose to marry a tradie over a prince () It's a result that will give heart to ordinary blokes the world over.Aussie women would much rather marry a tradie than a prince, a new survey by The Australian Women's Weekly has found. Perhaps dreaming of a DIY-free life, ladies also say they would take a tradie over a millionaire, an actor or sportsman, the survey of 1000 people found. "I think it's a very Australian result," the magazine's editor-in-chief Helen McCabe told AAP. "Australian women are very down to earth and that's reflected in this result." She said we like to admire royal romances from afar, but most realise it is not a realistic lifestyle. The lifestyle of a tradie however, which Ms McCabe described as getting up early, knocking off early then going for a beer, was pretty desirable for women. And although Prince William's wedding has whipped up a right royal frenzy, the survey revealed Australia's fondness for the monarchy is on a knife-edge. A total of 52 per cent think the nation should remain a monarchy. The majority (82 per cent) want William to be the next king, not Charles. And 75 per cent back William's decision to give Kate his mum's ring. On the issue of favourite royals, Diana is still tops, the survey found. She had 45 per cent support, equal to that of Crown Princess Mary - the Aussie who famously married into the Danish royal family after meeting Prince Frederik in a Sydney pub. The poll is published in Australian Women's Weekly, on sale on December 22.

event_or_fact.property: we like to admire royal romances from afar, but most realise it is not a realistic lifestyle
I think it's a very Australian result; Australian women are very down to earth and that's reflected in this result.

description.hltext_display: Understanding the importance of a lawn aerator
description.content:
To introduce, a lawn aerator is a garden tool to aerate or introduce air into the soil of the lawn. Regular aeration of the lawn improves soil drainage and encourages growth of worms, micro-fauna and micro-flora. Further, aeration of lawn involves two tasks. First, one needs to control lawn thatch and secondly, soil compaction must be discouraged.
Lawn thatch is a layer of dead organic material that deprives the soil from much needed nutrients (i.e. water & air). Air and water are the external factors which cannot infiltrate into the soil and reach the grass roots if the soil is in a compressed condition. Consequently, grass on the surface begins to die. Lawn aerators ensure easy absorption of water, oxygen and other nutrients to the grass roots. Lawn aeration also helps increase the vitality of the microorganisms, which prevents accumulation of lawn thatch.
Ways to aerate your lawn
There are two ways to aerate your lawn, one with the solid spike aerator and second with the lawn plug aerator.
While the former aerator with spikes simply punches holes into the ground, the lawn plug aerators pull out plugs of soil as well. These plugged holes can be later filled back with top soil and fertilizer. Out of the two methods, lawn plug aeration is said to be effective because actual cores of soil are pulled from the lawn. This process of lawn aeration helps the soil to open up. It also increases the water infiltration, improves rooting and reduces thatch, thereby improving the overall lawn condition.
Further, lawn aeration extends you many other advantages, in addition to minimal soil compaction and better drainage, like:
It increases the air flow in the soil which helps the grass roots to breathe better and grow healthier Improves lawn thickness and vigor Helps penetrate the fertilizer till the grass roots Save water waste by increasing water infiltration and reduces water run-off Air penetration increases the microbial activity in the soil Helps breaking lawn thatch Promotes a greener and weed free lawn
Finally, to help lawn soil breathe, it is advisable to give it some time to regenerate (after aeration and before seeding). This ensures uniform grass growth.

description.hltext_display: Nvidia SLI Technology,Intel form ultimate gaming PC
description.author: prajakta
description.content:
Nvidia SLI Technology has been licensed by the world’s leading motherboard manufacturers – including Intel, Asus, Gigabyte, MSI and EVGA for use on their Intel P67 Express Chipset-based motherboards designed for the upcoming Intel Sandy Bridge processors. As a result, customers who purchase a SLI-certified P67-based motherboard and a Sandy Bridge processor can equip their PCs with any single or dual combination of Nvidia GeForce GPUs, including the recently released GeForce GTX 580 GPU, the world’s fastest DX11 GPU.
“The combined processing prowess of Sandy Bridge and Nvidia SLI technology will provide consumers with the building blocks for the ultimate gaming PC platform,” said Joel Christensen, General Manager of Intel Client Board Division at Intel Corporation. “Both Nvidia and Intel continue to share a combined passion for furthering the PC as the definitive platform for gaming, and this combination will surely be attractive to anyone building or purchasing a brand new PC in 2011.” Nvidia SLI technology is now available for all consumer-based desktop and mobile PC platforms, including the Intel Core i7, Core i5, Core i3, Core 2 Quad and Core 2 Duo processors, as well as those based on the AMD Phenom II CPU.

event_or_fact.property: ?The combined processing prowess of Sandy Bridge and Nvidia SLI technology will provide consumers with the building blocks for the ultimate gaming PC platform,?

description.hltext_display: Jack Black hops on a Swift boat to Lilliput
description.content:
(Enlarge)
Movie review
Casting Jack Black in an updated version of Jonathan Swift's 18th-century novel "Gulliver's Travels" does not seem like a very promising idea, but the result turns out to be a surprisingly diverting comic adventure.
Although small kids are its natural audience, their towering parents also are likely to enjoy this visit to Lilliput.
Many current movies are being released in 3D, regardless of whether the material really merits that extra dimension. "Gulliver's Travels" clearly does benefit from the 3D treatment, because the entire story revolves around the discrepancy in scale between Gulliver and the Lilliputians.
Fortunately, director Rob Letterman does not go overboard with the computer-driven effects.
"Gulliver's Travels" is Letterman's first live-action movie, following the animated features "Monsters vs. Aliens" and "Shark Tale." He's not exactly subtle in guiding his live actors, but he gives them plenty of screen time in which to establish their characters, bumble their way through a silly story, and make a family-friendly impression.
It's probably best to take this discrepancy-driven, slapstick-filled star vehicle on its own terms and not worry about whether it's faithful to its literary source.
Swift definitely had satirical targets, whereas Letterman and his creative colleagues are just out to have fun.
In any event, nobody in the movie shows any awareness of Swift's novel. Although the New York newspaper mailroom clerk played by Jack Black is named Lemuel Gulliver, nobody at the office remarks on his sharing that famous literary name. Indeed, nobody even teases him for having such a weird first name.
This hefty Lemuel is an otherwise little guy who lacks stature in the newspaper office and elsewhere. He has been doing the same lowly job for a decade while nursing a secret crush on an unresponsive editor (Amanda Peet) and living in what verges on social invisibility.
Although he's prone to making blustery pronouncements, everybody sees right through his big claims. He's so pathetic that he often ends up making such boastful statements when he is by himself. Similarly, his air guitar performances typically have an audience of one. This guitar fixation owes nothing to Swift, of course, but a lot to Black's role in "School of Rock."
In a desperate bid to improve his rank in the office, Gulliver resorts to plagiarism in order to convince an editor that he's talented enough for a writing job.
One fast cinematic edit later, Gulliver has been promoted to a travel writer position and sent on assignment to the Bermuda Triangle. A few stormy moments later, he finds himself transported to Lilliput.
Initially taken prisoner by the tiny Lilliputians, Gulliver is able to sweet talk their princess (Emily Blunt) and other members of the royal household into believing that he's a friendly giant. Moreover, he shows that he's capable of being a one-man army against a rival kingdom.
Having witnessed Gulliver's boastful personality during his newsroom days, you won't be surprised by his eagerness to tell tall tales that are even taller than he is. When his tiny subjects believe everything he says, Gulliver's growing self-confidence expands to monstrous proportions. He even persuades the adoring populace to build a simulated Times Square in which all of the billboards advertise Broadway shows and commercial products that play off his name.
These pop culture-ribbing references ensure that this venerable story becomes a glib 21st-century tale.
The movie is not exactly profound and, for that matter, tends to be shamelessly obvious with its literally tall tale humor. It will make kids giggle, and that's what counts here. Grade: B
"Gulliver's Travels" (PG) opens Christmas Day, Dec. 25, at area theaters.

event_or_fact.property: Gulliver's growing self-confidence expands to monstrous proportions

description.hltext_display: Leafs stocked with promising net prospects
description.author: Adam Proteau, Metro Toronto
description.content:
Maple Leafs GM Brian Burke will tell anyone who’ll listen that he builds his teams starting from the net, moving out toward the defense corps, and, finally, with the forwards.
Burke has been true to that blueprint since he got to Toronto by signing Jonas Gustavsson and acquiring Jean-Sebastien Giguere from Anaheim last season. But of late, it appears the Leafs’ net situation isn’t quite as solidified for the future as he might like.
Yet, while there are worrisome signs regarding the Buds’ backstoppers, the truth is somewhat more comforting.
First, the troubling stuff: Giguere has continued to have problems with his groin — and struggled on the ice, as evidenced by an .894 save percentage and 2.80 goals against average, and Gustavsson (3.10 G.A.A., .894 save percentage) has looked equally inconsistent.
The better news is Burke has hedged his organization’s bets by stockpiling a number of goaltending prospects, including Finnish netminder Jussi Rynnas and Canadians Ben Scrivens and James Reimer. All three have accomplishments on their resumes that suggest they could get a shot at the Leafs’ net duties sooner or later.
Rynnas is a rookie to the North American game, but with Toronto’s American League affiliate, he’s been named an AHL player of the week and has an impressive .922 save percentage in 18 games with the Marlies this season.
Reimer also has good numbers (including a 7-3-1 record, .920 save percentage and three shutouts) with the Marlies. And Scrivens, who began the year with Toronto’s ECHL affiliate, was named the top goalie in one conference of NCAA Division 1 hockey last season.
Burke doesn’t need any one of the four (including Gustavsson) in particular to pan out – but he desperately needs at least one of them to prove Toronto’s scouts and player developers were right to sign them.
If that can’t happen, Burke will be forced to look at trades or signings to address the position. And as is painfully evident, he doesn’t have many organizational assets with which to tempt other GMs.
For the sake of Leafs fans, let’s hope it won’t come to that.

description.hltext_display: Viking Linen laivatilaus tuo työtä tuhansille
description.content:
Viking Linen laivatilaus STX Finlandilta tuo merkittävästi työpaikkoja Turun seudulle. Laivayhtiö varmisti tilauskensa tänään. Uuden risteilijän rakentaminen merkitsee telakkayhtiölle noin 2 600 henkilötyövuotta eli työtä riittää tuhansille ihmisille.
- Olemme kiitollisia hankkeemme saamasta, monien eri yhteistyökumppaneiden ja -tahojen tuesta sekä erityisen iloisia siitä, että pystymme näin joulun alla lupaamaan uutta työtä tuhansille ihmisille Turun seudulla, sanoo toimitusjohtaja Mikael Backman.
Yksi Viking Linen ehdoista koski ympäristötukea, jonka liikenne- ja viestintäministeriö myönsi eilen. Sopimus sisältää myös option toisesta laivasta. Investointi on noin 240 miljoonan euron arvoinen.
Alus rakennetaan Turun-telakalla, ja se tulee TurkuAhvenanmaaTukholma-reitille. Laivan arvioidaan valmistuvan vuoden 2013 alussa. Uusi laiva on noin 214 metriä pitkä ja se on suunniteltu 2800 matkustajalle. Sitä operoi 200 hengen miehistö. Jotain meni pieleen, pahoittelemme. Koita hetken päästä uudelleen.
